A follow-up review should also be done in two weeks.

Prolonged use of systemic and topical steroids
Use of pomades, especially products that contain lanolin, petrolatum, vegetable oils, butyl stearate, lauryl alcohol and oleic acid

INVESTIGATIONS: Serum testosterone (in females with accompanying hirsutism and virilizing features)

Petechiae and purpura (in bone marrow failure)

ANTIBIOTIC_PROPHYLAXIS.Introduction: Antibiotic prophylaxis refers to the administration of antibiotics in patients to reduce the risk of perioperative sepsis. The main cause of morbidity and mortality in surgery is infectious complications. Antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated in cases where sepsis is expected and could have disastrous local or generalized effects. For prophylaxis to be effective, antibiotics must be given before contamination takes place or at the earliest possible time before infection is established.
Causes: Coagulase negative staphylococci (especially cardiac surgery, and implantation surgery), etc.

Proven Indications: Surgery on the colon and rectum
Gastro-oesophageal and oro-pharyngeal surgery for carcinoma
Surgery in the presence of pus
Accepted Indications: Implant surgery where prosthesis and device implants are used

ANTIBIOTIC_PROPHYLAXIS.ChoiceOfAntibiotics: The antibiotic chosen must have antibacterial activity against the anticipated pathogens, not easily induce antimicrobial resistance, have a high concentration at the site of infection, be safely metabolized and excreted, have few toxic or adverse reactions, and be affordable.

BipolarDisorder.MoodStates: Affected patients present with one predominant mood state at a time, either depression or mania.

Chronic Bronchitis.Introduction: This is chronic inflammation of the bronchial mucosa due to irritants such as tobacco smoke. It occurs after the age of 40 years and is part of the syndrome of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). There is progressive worsening with age, eventually resulting in chronic respiratory failure. It is aggravated by recurrent viral and bacterial infections. Oxygen therapy in these patients must be given with caution to prevent carbon dioxide retention due to depression of respiration. High flow rates remove the central hypoxic drive that maintains respiratory effort and can be harmful.
Causes: Inhaled smoke from the use of biomass fuels (e.g. charcoal, wood)
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, particularly on exertion
Cough with production of sputum for most of the year

To reduce the quantity of sputum produced

Chronic Hepatitis.Introduction: Chronic Hepatitis refers to chronic inflammation of the liver of more than 6 months duration, with persistently elevated liver function tests. Chronic hepatitis can progress to liver cirrhosis, portal hypertension with upper gastrointestinal bleeding, hepatic encephalopathy, and hepatocellular carcinoma. Immunization against Hepatitis B is now available for children under the Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI). Adults in endemic areas including Ghana should be immunized against Hepatitis B infection after the initial assessment of their immunological status regarding previous exposure to the virus.

Treatment Objectives: To prevent disease progression and complications
To prevent hepatic encephalopathy
To improve synthetic liver function through viral suppression
To prevent transmission
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer all cases of chronic hepatitis B infection to a specialist, especially those who have failed first-line anti-viral therapy or had adverse reactions to anti-viral therapy or have liver-related complications.

Chronic Kidney Disease.Introduction: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) refers to kidney damage of more than 3 months duration. The early stage of CKD is usually asymptomatic but can be detected through laboratory tests of serum creatinine and estimation of Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR), measurement of urine albumin creatinine ratio and screening of individuals at increased risk such as those with hypertension, diabetes mellitus or a past history of glomerulonephritis. CKD may manifest either as urine abnormalities, blood abnormalities, and structural kidney changes on ultrasonography or all stages of CKD, patients should be encouraged to cease smoking, reduce weight if obese, check lipids and treat, and avoid NSAIDs and other nephrotoxic drugs.

To control hypertension
To control blood glucose
To manage underlying causes
To prevent complications and further worsening of kidney function

Constipation.introduction: In general, constipation refers to bowel movements that are infrequent or stools that are difficult to pass. There is great individual variation in normal bowel habits; therefore emphasis should be laid on changes in the bowel habit.
Constipation.Note: Diarrhoea alternating with constipation may indicate a large bowel cancer especially in those aged 40 years and above. In children and the elderly, this may indicate chronic constipation with spurious diarrhoea. The habitual use of laxatives is very common in the community. This practice must be discouraged to avoid hypokalaemia and its consequences.

Medical: Ignoring the urge to defaecate e.g. due to immobility
Drugs e.g. atropine, codeine, morphine, tricyclic antidepressants, disopyramide
Lazy bowel from chronic laxative use including 'herbal' preparations
Surgical: Anal fissure and other painful perianal lesions
Carcinoma of the rectum and sigmoid colon
Pseudo-bowel obstruction (Ogilvie syndrome) following immobility from any cause

List: Feeling of incomplete evacuation of bowel
Inability to pass flatus, colicky abdominal pain with or without vomiting

Non-pharmacological treatment: Adequate fluid intake (minimum of 3.2L of water per day if no contraindications exist)

COVID-19.cause: The disease is caused by a novel coronavirus named Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
COVID-19.spread_of_disease: The disease spreads primarily from person to person through droplets produced when people sneeze, cough, speak, or exhale. These droplets can land on surfaces, and the virus can be transmitted when individuals touch contaminated surfaces and then their mucosal surfaces (eyes, nose, mouth) with their hands. Additionally, aerosol transmission is possible in enclosed spaces with high concentrations of droplets.

adults: Commonly dry cough, but may be productive
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Loss or reduced sense of smell (anosmia or hyposmia)

signs: Use of accessory muscles for respiration (plus intercostal in-drawing, etc.)
Restricted chest wall movement (unilateral or bilateral)
Signs of lung consolidation on chest examination
Low blood oxygen saturation measured by pulse oximeter (SPO2 < 93%)

mild: Non-specific symptoms such as fever, fatigue, cough (with or without sputum production), loss of appetite (anorexia), malaise, muscle pain, sore throat, difficulty breathing (dyspnoea), nasal congestion, or headache. In rare cases, patients may also present with gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.
pneumonia: Adults with pneumonia but no signs of severe pneumonia and no need for supplemental oxygen

Children with non-severe pneumonia who have cough or difficulty breathing and fast breathing: Fast breathing rates (in breaths per minute): < 2 months: ≥ 60; 2-11 months: ≥ 50; 1-5 years: ≥ 40. These children should not exhibit signs of severe pneumonia.
severe_pneumonia: Adolescents or adults: Fever or suspected respiratory illness, rapid breathing (tachypnea), rapid heart rate (tachycardia), cyanosis, and signs of lung consolidation on chest examination

treatment: There are currently no well-researched and approved vaccines, medicines, or blood products specifically for the prevention and treatment of patients with COVID-19.
Clinical management includes infection prevention and control (IPC) measures and supportive care.

Cushing's Syndrome.introduction: This condition results from high levels of cortisol in the blood and is associated with various changes in the body including the development of obesity, hypertension, diabetes and osteoporosis. The prolonged use or abuse (especially by women for cosmetic reasons) of oral or topical corticosteroids such as prednisolone, dexamethasone, hydrocortisone or cortisone, or preparations containing any of these drugs, is also a cause.
causes: Prolonged and excessive intake (for asthma, nephrotic syndrome etc.) or abuse of corticosteroids
signs: Easy bruising and bleeding into the skin after venepuncture
Inability to rise from the squatting position
investigations: Plasma cortisol (commonly elevated in pituitary and adrenal tumours, but low in corticosteroid use or abuse)
Abdominal ultrasound scan (may show an adrenal tumour)
CT scan (may show evidence of a pituitary or adrenal tumour)

objectives: To normalise plasma level of cortisol
To prevent complications of excess plasma cortisol
non_pharmacological: Pituitary or adrenal surgery where tumours in the respective glands have been diagnosed
pharmacological: Treatment is dependent on the cause and requires specialized investigations. Manage hypertension and diabetes along standard lines and refer patient for definitive treatment.

Cushing's Syndrome.referral_criteria: Refer all suspected cases to an endocrinologist or specialist physician in a regional or teaching hospital for the appropriate investigations and management.

Dental Caries.introduction: Dental caries is a tooth surface cavity caused by acid demineralization of tooth hard tissue. It occurs as a result bacterial conversion of refined carbohydrates to acids, which in prolonged contact with tooth surface leads to the demineralisation. This process is entirely preventable but can progress to severe decay and tooth loss or complicated by infection.
causes: Acid demineralisation of hard tooth surface
symptoms: Toothache precipitated by hot, cold or sweet foods or drinks
Pain may be intermittent or severe, sharp and constant if the nerve endings are exposed
signs: A hole or black spot may be visible on any surface of a tooth
Tenderness on percussion of the affected tooth

objectives: To arrest process by excavation and filling of cavities
To educate on good dental habits
non_pharmacological: Regular mouth rinse after refined carbohydrate intake

Dental Caries.referral_criteria: Refer patient to a dentist for definitive treatment.

Depression.introduction: Depression is a mood disorder, which may occur in all age groups, although the symptoms may differ in children. It is a relatively common condition and has a tendency to recur. Some affected persons may turn out to have bipolar disorder, in which case, episodes of mania occur.

prevalence.major_depression_women: Clinically significant depression, also called major depression, is twice as common in women as in men.
prevalence.spiritual_and_traditional_healers: Many affected individuals seek help from spiritual and traditional healers. For a good proportion of those who go to hospitals, their condition is not recognized.

impact.morbidity_and_suicide: Depression is a significant cause of morbidity all over the world and most people who attempt or successfully complete suicide have depression.
impact.warning_signs: One should not dismiss or take for granted statements made by patients such as 'I want to die', 'life is not worth living', or 'I am fed up with life'. All cases of attempted suicide should be referred to a psychiatrist after initial management of the presenting complication e.g. self-inflicted injuries or poisoning.

types.recurrent_vs_unipolar: Recurrent depression or unipolar depression is treated differently (with antidepressants) from bipolar depression, which responds more to mood stabilizers.

diagnosis.criteria: The diagnostic criteria for major depression relies on the presence of at least five (5) of the symptoms, experienced every day for at least two weeks.

treatment.antidepressant_duration: In the treatment of depression, maximum tolerable doses of antidepressant medications must be given for at least 6 weeks before deciding a particular medication is not effective.
treatment.post_episode_treatment: After an episode of depression, treatment must be continued for at least 6 months, as there is a high risk of relapse within this period.
treatment.management_of_manic_swing: Antidepressants must be stopped immediately if a manic swing occurs. Patients with suicidal tendencies must be admitted and kept under close observation.

common: Depressed mood, often reported as feeling 'out of sorts'
Loss of interest or lack of pleasure in things previously of interest
Significant weight loss or weight gain
Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt
Suicidal ideas or thoughts of death
Hallucinations or delusions of morbid themes in severe cases
in_children: Truancy or refusal to go to school
Some of the 'adult' symptoms listed above

signs: Evidence of weight loss or weight gain
investigations: Thyroid function and cortisol levels if indicated
Administer a standardized scale of depression such as the PHQ (patient health questionnaire 9 item scale)

Diabetes_Mellitus.introduction: Diabetes mellitus is characterized by persistently elevated blood glucose levels. If left untreated or improperly treated for long periods this will result in widespread blood vessel damage and complications relating to the eyes, kidneys, heart, brain and nerves. There is an increased risk of lower limb amputations, poor fertility and pregnancy outcomes with improper glucose control.

presentation.acute_symptoms_children: Although children and adolescents often present with acute symptoms, many adults with diabetes are asymptomatic.
presentation.need_for_diagnosis: It is therefore necessary to exclude diabetes in all persons, especially adults, attending health facilities for routine medical examinations, first out-patient review, ante-natal care, elective and emergency admissions or undergoing surgical procedures.

management.lifelong_interventions: The non-pharmacological and pharmacological interventions in diabetes management are usually life-long.
management.diagnosis_confirmation: Individuals found to have venous or capillary plasma glucose levels in the pre-diabetes or diabetes ranges will need further assessment to confirm the diagnosis.

types.secondary: Secondary diabetes (related to medication use, endocrine or pancreatic disease etc.)

type_2.genetic_factors: causing a defect in the action or secretion of insulin
type_2.environmental_factors: e.g. excessive calorie intake and lack of physical activity

signs.feet_or_hands_sensation: Lack of sensation in the feet or hands

newly_diagnosed: Oral glucose tolerance test (if required to confirm diagnosis)
Urine ketones (with high initial glucose levels)
routine_follow_ups: Recorded results of regular self-monitoring of fasting and random tests at home by the patient using a glucose meter
Periodic fasting or random tests during clinic reviews
Glycated haemoglobin (HbA1c) (at least twice a year)
Blood lipid tests (annually, but more frequently if levels abnormal or on lipid lowering medication)
Blood urea, electrolytes and creatinine (annually, but more frequently if levels abnormal)

glycaemic_targets.fasting_blood_glucose: Fasting blood glucose between 4-7 mmol/L (less intensive glycaemic targets in elderly patients)
glycaemic_targets.2hr_post_meal_blood_glucose: 2-hour post-meal blood glucose between 5-9 mmol/L (less intensive glycaemic targets in elderly patients)
glycaemic_targets.glycated_haemoglobin: Glycated haemoglobin 7% or less (less intensive glycaemic targets in elderly patients)

objectives.weight_reduction: To ensure weight reduction in overweight and obese individuals

diet.avoid_refined_sugars: Avoid refined sugars as in soft drinks
diet.day's_diet: A day's diet must generally consist of carbohydrates (60%), protein (15%) and fat (20%) mostly of plant-origin and low in animal fat
diet.soluble_fibre: Soluble fibre (e.g. as found in oats, beans, apples, nuts etc.)
diet.reduced_caloric_content: A reduced total caloric portion of food and an increase in the amount of fibre e.g. vegetables, fruits and cereals
diet.alcohol: Intake of alcohol is prohibited for individuals less than 18 years of age. While low consumption is permissible in adult patients, moderate to heavy drinking of alcohol increases the total caloric intake and may worsen overweight and obesity. It may also increase the risk of hypoglycaemia
diet.exercise: Regular, simple exercise e.g. 30 minutes brisk walking at least 3 days a week in ambulant patients

type_1_and_type_2_insulin_monotherapy.insulin_dose_requirements: Insulin dose requirements vary from patient to patient irrespective of age and body weight
type_1_and_type_2_insulin_monotherapy.total_daily_insulin_requirement: The total daily insulin requirement for most adults and pre-pubertal children is about 0.6-0.8 units/kg, which should be given in divided doses. However, it is prudent to begin with lower doses and build this up with time to prevent hypoglycaemia
type_1_and_type_2_insulin_monotherapy.increased_insulin_requirements: Insulin requirements increase during infections, puberty, periods of stress, accidental or surgical trauma, pregnancy etc.

insulin_injections.usual_route: The usual route for insulin injections for outpatient diabetes treatment is sub-cutaneous

timing_regimens.regular_soluble_insulin: Regular/soluble insulin, premix insulin, or NPH insulin 30 minutes before a meal
timing_regimens.rapid_acting_analogues: Rapid acting analogue insulins (e.g. aspart, lispro) immediately before the meal

referral_criteria.dietician: All individuals with diabetes must be referred to a dietician for dietary advice.
referral_criteria.children_specialist: All children with diabetes must be seen by a specialist (paediatrician or endocrinologist).
referral_criteria.glycaemic_targets_unachieved: All patients in whom glycaemic targets cannot be achieved as well as those with diabetes complications must be referred to the appropriate specialist.
referral_criteria.eye_specialist: All type 2 diabetics at diagnosis and type 1 diabetics 5 years after diagnosis should be referred to an eye specialist for screening for Diabetic Retinopathy.

Diabetes_Mellitus_in_Pregnancy.introduction: Diabetes Mellitus in pregnancy includes individuals known to be diabetic prior to pregnancy and those who develop impaired glucose tolerance during pregnancy. Gestational diabetes refers to impaired glucose tolerance of any degree that develops or is first recognized during the current pregnancy, irrespective of whether it resolves after delivery or not. Diabetes is associated with poor health outcomes for a mother and her baby if not properly managed.

screening.gestational_diabetes: Many patients with gestational diabetes are asymptomatic making screening for all pregnant women mandatory to identify those at risk.
screening.blood_glucose_test: A fasting blood glucose test must be done on all pregnant women at booking and also at 28-32 weeks.

management.multidisciplinary_approach: The management of diabetes mellitus in pregnancy and the puerperium involves close monitoring of the woman by a multidisciplinary approach comprising a team of obstetricians, midwives, nurses, dieticians, physicians, anaesthetists and paediatricians.
management.labour_and_caesarean_section: Labour (induced or spontaneous) and Caesarean section are best supervised in hospital under specialist care.
management.post_delivery_treatment: Anti-diabetic treatment requirements reduce dramatically after delivery hence, post delivery treatment doses must be tailored to each individual patient's needs.
management.newborn_baby_care: The newborn baby of a diabetic mother needs special care and is best managed by a paediatrician/neonatologist.

previous_history: Previous history of large babies (> 4 kg)
Previous poor obstetric history (foetal deaths, miscarriages)

ultrasound_scans: Serial scans for growth assessment in third trimester
urine_and_blood_tests: Blood glucose profile (Fasting blood glucose and 2-hour post-prandial blood glucose monthly in the lab; more frequently by self-monitoring)

objectives: To achieve normal blood glucose and glycated haemoglobin levels throughout pregnancy, labour, delivery and puerperium
To prevent maternal and foetal complications
To prevent neonatal morbidity and mortality
To detect and manage other associated complications e.g. pre-eclampsia

non_pharmacological.general_measures: General measures (dietary modification, exercise, patient counselling and education, blood glucose monitoring must be discussed with a dietician, obstetrician or midwife, respectively)
delivery: by 40 weeks gestation: in well controlled patients with no complications
by 38 weeks gestation; in Insulin treated patients and those with complications
Caesarean section; for patients with either of the following;
If elective preterm delivery is necessary, mature the foetal lungs with corticosteroids under specialist care
Puerperium: Close blood glucose monitoring in the first 48 hours after delivery

pharmacological.before_planned_pregnancy: Before planned pregnancy: Optimize glycaemic control in known diabetics before pregnancy.
during_pregnancy: If diet alone cannot control the blood glucose level consider hypoglycaemic agents: metformin, glibenclamide and insulin
Diabetic patients on oral medication who become pregnant can be maintained on their oral medication if sugar control is satisfactory
Indications for oral antidiabetic agents use

pharmacological.glibenclamide: Glibenclamide, oral, 5-5 mg 12-24 hourly. Increase dose by 5 mg if necessary until max. dose of 15 mg/day

Diabetic_Ketoacidosis.introduction: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a condition associated with high blood glucose (usually > 18 mmol/L), which nonetheless, is unavailable to the body tissues as a source of energy. Fat is therefore broken down as an alternative source of energy, releasing toxic chemicals called ketones as a by-product. Additionally, there is severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalance in DKA, especially low potassium. It is a common cause of death among diabetes patients in Ghana.
causes: Stress of intercurrent illness (e.g. infection, myocardial infarction, stroke, surgery, complicated pregnancy etc.)
symptoms: Symptoms of infection or other underlying condition
signs: Dehydration (dry skin, reduced skin turgor or sunken eyes)
Evidence of infection, recent surgery, stroke etc.

investigations.blood_urea_and_electrolytes: Blood urea and electrolytes (usually low potassium, however if in renal failure urea and potassium may be high)
other_tests: Full blood count (raised white cell count would suggest bacterial infection)
Electrocardiogram (to identify hypokalaemia, and in adult patients to exclude acute myocardial infarction as a precipitating factor)

objectives: To replace the electrolyte losses, especially potassium
To seek the underlying cause and treat appropriately

pharmacological.management_of_HONK: B. Management of Hyperosmolar Non-Ketotic state (HONK) (See 'Management of DKA' above)
adjunct_treatment: Treat malaria if suspected or confirmed

referral_criteria.inadequate_resources: If there are inadequate resources for managing the patient, start 0.9% Sodium Chloride, IV, and give initial dose of soluble or regular insulin IV or IM after confirming blood glucose and urine ketone levels and refer to a nearby regional or teaching hospital.
referral_criteria.coma_or_inadequate_urine_output: If the patient remains comatose or fails to pass adequate amounts of urine despite management, refer to a regional or teaching hospital for further care.

Diarrhoea.introduction: Diarrhoea is defined as the passage of frequent, loose, watery stools 3 or more times a day. Diarrhoea may be accompanied by vomiting. In children, the commonest cause is viral. There is usually no need to prescribe antibiotics for viral diarrhoea. Other diseases like malaria, pneumonia, ear infections, and urinary tract infections may be associated with diarrhoea. If not corrected, diarrhoea may lead to dehydration, which can be fatal.

acute_diarrhoea: Bacterial: e.g. Salmonella spp., Shigella, Campylobacter, E. coli, Vibrio cholerae
chronic_diarrhoea: Chronic infections: e.g. amoebiasis, tuberculosis, opportunistic infections with HIV
Inflammatory: e.g. ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
Endocrine: e.g. hyperthyroidism, diabetic autonomic neuropathy

symptoms: Blood or mucus in the stool

adults: Oral lesions e.g. oral ulcers, candidiasis
Signs of dehydration (dry mucous membranes, reduction in skin turgor, capillary refill > 2 seconds, tachycardia, postural hypotension)

objectives: To eliminate infecting organisms where appropriate
non-pharmacological: Adequate fluid intake - oral and intravenous as necessary
Maintain adequate nutrition as can be tolerated
referral_criteria: Refer patients who fail to improve or get worse despite therapy for acute diarrhoea
Refer all patients with chronic diarrhoea to a specialist for further evaluation and management

Diphtheria.introduction: Diphtheria is a disease caused by bacteria that produce a toxin damaging human tissues and organs, commonly affecting the tonsils and skin. It spreads through respiratory droplets or skin contact. Symptoms can be severe, and complications include abnormal heartbeat, heart failure, valve damage, and respiratory obstruction. Immunization has reduced its prevalence.
symptoms: Difficulty in breathing with or without stridor
signs: Greyish white membrane or patch in the throat and on tonsils within 2-3 days of symptom onset
Membrane may bleed, become greyish green or black
investigations: Throat/nasal swabs for culture for index case and close contacts
Repeat swabs after antibiotic treatment course

objectives: Eradicate the organism from the pharynx
non-pharmacological: Feeding by nasogastric tube for patients who cannot swallow
referral_criteria: Refer patients with laryngeal obstruction or respiratory paralysis to an ENT specialist

Dislocation.introduction: Dislocation refers to the dissociation of articular surfaces. It's important to assess and document the neuro-vascular status of the limb(s) involved after a dislocation due to nearby structures. Causes include various accidents and injuries.
investigations: CT scan or MRI if available
CT angiogram or Doppler scan (if vascular status assessment is abnormal)

objectives: Save a life first - ATLS (advanced trauma life support)
Achieve a stable reduction of the dislocated joint
non-pharmacological: Keep nil per os until reduction has been achieved
referral_criteria: Refer all complicated dislocations to an orthopaedic specialist

Dizziness.introduction: Dizziness refers to abnormal sensations of body orientation or position in space, including unsteadiness, light-headedness, and vertigo. It is often difficult for patients to describe. Dizziness is usually associated with other symptoms, so a thorough history and physical examination are important for identifying the cause.

cardiovascular: Complete heart block with Stokes-Adams attacks

symptoms: Sense of motion or spinning of body

signs.neurological: Nystagmus, dysdiadochokinesis, ataxia, hypotonia, dysarthria (suggests cerebellar cause)
signs.focal_neurological: Focal neurological signs suggest stroke, TIA

investigations: These vary depending on the cause

objectives: To identify and appropriately manage the possible underlying cause(s)
pharmacological: Identify and treat the underlying cause
referral_criteria: Refer patients to a physician specialist for evaluation if the cause is difficult to determine
If the cause is identified, refer to the appropriate specialist for further evaluation and management

Drug Resistant Tuberculosis.introduction: Drug-resistant tuberculosis (DR-TB) is presumed in patients who remain bacteriologically positive after standard first-line TB treatment. Rifampicin-resistant patients are also treated as DR-TB cases. Evaluations using TB culture and Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST) are essential. Risk factors include treatment failure, contacts of confirmed DR-TB patients, and TB/HIV co-infected patients not improving on treatment.

high_risk: TB patients failing Category I+III or Category II treatment
TB/HIV co-infected patients not improving on treatment
medium_risk: Health care workers newly diagnosed with TB

selection: History of drugs used for TB treatment
Profile of drug resistance in Ghana and/or DST profile of the patient
Minimum of four new core medicines known to be effective
Kanamycin/Capreomycin as injectable medicine in the intensive phase
Effective fluoroquinolone due to extensive use of earlier generation fluoroquinolones
Possible inclusion of a first-line drug to which the strain is susceptible
treatment_principles.administration: Administered daily under strict D0T throughout the injectable and continuation phases
treatment_duration: Adoption of a shorter treatment regime (9-12 months) in Ghana
treatment_principles.community_care: Promote community-based care over facility-based care, with infection prevention and control maintained
treatment_principles.adherence: Critical due to limited effective medicines; Patient-centered care approach and support required throughout treatment

referral_criteria: Refer all patients to a DOTS treatment center for management and monitoring under the Ghana National Tuberculosis Program

Drug Induced Liver Injury.introduction: Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI) can result from various medications. A high index of suspicion is important for diagnosis. Early recognition is crucial for withdrawing the offending drug, assessing severity, and monitoring for acute liver failure. DILI can be dose-dependent or idiosyncratic. Early withdrawal of the offending drug is the hallmark of treatment.

causes.allopathic_drugs: Prescription, over-the-counter, anesthetic agents (e.g. paracetamol, statins, isoniazid, halothane, amiodarone, azathioprine, carbamazepine, phenytoin, nevirapine, ketoconazole, flucloxacillin, etc.)

signs.pre_existing_chronic_liver_disease: Signs of pre-existing chronic liver disease

investigations: Hepatitis screen (A, B, C, E) for exclusion

objectives: To identify and withdraw the offending agent
To report adverse drug events to Food and Drugs Authority (FDA) promptly
To assess severity of liver disease
To administer antidote where applicable or feasible
non-pharmacological: Avoidance of prolonged recumbency and dehydration
Avoidance of excess amounts of coffee, tea, and alcohol
referral_criteria: Refer all patients failing to improve or showing progression in liver injury despite withdrawal of offending drug to a specialist

Deep Vein Thrombosis.introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is common, often asymptomatic, and can lead to serious complications. Risk factors include obesity, immobility, surgery, pregnancy, inherited disorders, etc. Prompt intervention is important. Treatment aims to prevent clot propagation and pulmonary embolism.
causes: Stagnation of blood in the vein
Inflammation of the blood vessel causing damage
symptoms: Swelling or firmness of affected limb (usually unilateral)
investigations: Thrombophilia screen (e.g. protein C, protein S levels)

objectives: To prevent clot propagation and pulmonary embolism
non-pharmacological: Avoidance of prolonged recumbency and dehydration
Regular exercise during long journeys or immobility periods
referral_criteria: Refer to physician specialist for management and monitoring

High Blood Cholesterol linked to Cardiov.introduction: High blood cholesterol levels are linked to cardiovascular disease (CVD) events. Reducing cholesterol levels in at-risk individuals is crucial for primary and secondary prevention. Commonly assessed lipid parameters include total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and triglycerides. Treatment targets primarily focus on LDL-cholesterol levels.
causes: High dietary intake of saturated fats (animal fat)
symptoms: Abdominal pain from pancreatitis related to hypertriglyceridemia

signs.corneal_arcus: Whitish ring around the cornea (corneal arcus)
signs.xanthelasmata: Yellowish skin eruptions around the eyes (xanthelasmata)

investigations: Thyroid function test (if lipid levels very high)
Plasma protein (if lipid levels very high, to exclude nephrotic syndrome)
Urine protein (if lipid levels very high, to exclude nephrotic syndrome)

objectives: To reduce the risk of clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular events and related deaths in at-risk individuals
To reduce LDL-C levels to specific targets
pharmacological: 1st Line Treatment: Simvastatin for low CVD risk
1st Line Treatment: Atorvastatin or Rosuvastatin for moderate CVD risk
1st Line Treatment: Atorvastatin or Rosuvastatin for high CVD risk
referral_criteria: Refer all patients who remain outside the target values despite adequate therapy to a specialist

Dysmenorrhea.introduction: Dysmenorrhea is cyclical lower abdominal pain associated with menstruation. It can be primary or secondary. It is often caused by uterine contractions. Treatment aims to relieve pain and address underlying causes.
symptoms: Radiating pain to lower back or legs

non-pharmacological: Warm pads applied to the lower abdomen
pharmacological: Severe Cases: Ibuprofen or Mefenamic Acid
referral_criteria: Refer to a gynecologist if pain interferes with normal activity or treatment is ineffective

Dyspnea.introduction: Dyspnea is the uncomfortable awareness of one's breathing. It's a common symptom of cardiopulmonary disease. Dyspnea of sudden onset is a medical emergency. It can have various causes related to cardiac, respiratory, or other factors.

cardiac: Valvular Heart Disease (mitral stenosis, aortic stenosis)

investigations: Cardiac enzymes, Troponin T, CK-MB (if ischemic heart disease is suspected)
CT pulmonary angiogram (useful for confirming PE)

referral_criteria: Refer to the next level of care if cause cannot be identified

Eclampsia.introduction: Eclampsia is a complication of worsening pre-eclampsia during pregnancy. It is characterized by high blood pressure, proteinuria, and convulsions (eclamptic fits). Treatment aims to protect the patient, control fits, lower blood pressure, monitor for complications, and deliver the baby when the mother is stable.

objectives: Monitor for organ failures and obstetric complications
Deliver the baby when the mother is stable
non-pharmacological: Do not put anything in patient's mouth
pharmacological: Fluid replacement (Sodium Chloride 0.9% or Ringer's lactate)
Treatment of convulsions not responding to Magnesium sulphate (Diazepam)
referral_criteria: Transfer all cases of eclampsia immediately to a hospital or obstetrician in a facility with operative capacity.

Eczema.introduction: Eczema or dermatitis is an acute or chronic inflammatory reaction in the skin often due to external (exogenous) or internal (endogenous) factors. It includes various types such as atopic eczema, seborrhoiec eczema, discoid eczema, asteatotic eczema, varicose eczema, and endogenous hand and soles dermatitis. Contact dermatitis may be irritant or allergic reactions to specific external substances. Treatment aims to relieve symptoms, identify and avoid triggers.

causes.irritants: Irritants (e.g. acids, alkalis, detergents, petroleum products)
causes.allergens: Allergens (e.g. nickel, rubber, additives, chromates, hair dyes, etc.)
causes.venous_stasis: Venous stasis (e.g. varicose veins, heart failure, lymphoedema)

investigations: Fasting blood sugar (seborrhoiec eczema in adults)

objectives: Identify and avoid causative or predisposing factors
pharmacological: Atopic Eczema: Various topical treatments (E45 cream, Aqueous cream, Shea butter, Salicylic Acid, etc.) and antihistamines
Seborrhoiec Eczema: Topical treatments (Miconazole, Clotrimazole, Ketoconazole, Selenium sulphide, Itraconazole) and systemic treatment if needed
Contact Dermatitis: Betamethasone cream/ointment, Mometasone lotion/ointment, etc.
referral_criteria: Refer patients not responding to treatment and those needing further investigations to a dermatologist

Epilepsy.introduction: Epilepsy is a disorder of the central nervous system characterized by spontaneous recurrent seizures or the tendency to have seizures. It's classified as Generalized (with aura and loss of consciousness) or Focal. Drug treatment depends on the type of seizure and is guided by specific principles. Anticonvulsant drug treatment can be withdrawn only after a 2-year seizure-free period and proper evaluation.
symptoms: Aura (may include a strange gut feeling, somatosensory manifestations - visual, olfactory, gustatory or auditory e.g. strange smells/flashing lights)
Muscle twitching and movements which may be focal or generalized
After a seizure, the patient may be confused (post-ictal confusion) or may sleep for some time (post-ictal sleep)
signs: A prodrome or aura with automatism (lip smacking, picking at items)
Muscle twitching and movements which may be focal or generalized
Todd’s paralysis (stroke-like weakness) may rarely occur
Examine carefully for evidence of neurological localizing signs, tongue laceration and evidence of trauma to the face or other parts of the body

non-pharmacological: Move sharp objects, fire etc. away from patient during seizures
Ensure clothing around the neck is loose
Ensure the airway is clear, wipe or suction any secretions or vomitus from the mouth or nose.
Do not force a spoon or tongue depressor into mouth!
After convulsions cease, turn the patient into semi-prone position by turning the patient on the side, with one leg bent and the other leg straight
pharmacological: Management of Epilepsy - Acute Generalized seizures
Management of Epilepsy - Generalized absence seizure
referral_criteria: Refer all patients with intractable seizures to the specialist

Epistaxis.introduction: Epistaxis, also called nosebleed, is a common medical emergency that requires prompt management to avoid morbidity and mortality. It can be caused by factors like picking the nose, trauma, sinonasal neoplasms, hypertension, bleeding disorders, and atrophic rhinitis. Treatment aims to stop the nosebleed, prevent recurrence, and address shock if severe.

causes.picking_nose: Picking of the nose, especially with an upper respiratory tract infection

objectives: To detect shock and replace blood if necessary
non-pharmacological: Sit patient up and flex head to prevent blood running down throat and airway
Pinch soft part of nose for 10 minutes (patient must breathe through mouth)
pharmacological: Haemostasis: Oxymetazoline nasal spray, Adrenaline topical (nose pack on cotton wool)
referral_criteria: Refer patients with recurrent or severe epistaxis to the ENT specialist

Erectile Dysfunction.introduction: Erectile dysfunction is the persistent inability to achieve an erection adequate for satisfactory sexual intercourse. It can be classified as organic, psychogenic, or mixed in terms of etiology. Causes include psychological factors, vascular issues, neurogenic conditions, endocrine disorders, drug-related factors, and more. Treatment aims to determine causative factors and restore sexual potency.

causes.psychogenic: Psychogenic factors like anxiety, depression, stress, marital conflict
causes.organic_vasculogenic: Vasculogenic factors: arterial insufficiency/occlusion; venous incompetence
causes.organic_neurogenic: Neurogenic factors: peripheral neuropathy; spinal cord lesions
causes.organic_traumatic: Traumatic factors: penectomy; pelvic fracture (with urethral rupture); perineal trauma
causes.organic_endocrine: Endocrine factors: diabetes mellitus, hypogonadism; hyperprolactinemia; pituitary, adrenal and thyroid disorders
causes.organic_mechanical: Mechanical factors: congenital penile abnormalities; Peyronie's disease
causes.organic_endurance: Endurance-related factors: heart/renal/liver failure; pulmonary insufficiency

female: Virilization changes (hirsutism, clitoromegaly, deepening of voice, etc.)
Abdominal masses due to uterine or ovarian enlargement
Abnormal vaginal discharge indicative of infection
male: Abnormal penile discharge indicative of infection
Testicular abnormalities e.g. varicoceles, small or absent testes

objectives: To treat the underlying cause of the infertility if possible
To achieve pregnancy within the shortest possible time
non-pharmacological: Assisted Reproduction Technologies (e.g., artificial insemination, in-vitro fertilization)
referral_criteria: Early referral of all patients with infertility to a specialist is preferred, particularly women with uterine, ovarian or tubal disease requiring surgery or who require ovulation induction not responsive to clomifene citrate. Also refer male partners for review by a urologist.

Exposure Keratopathy.introduction: Exposure keratopathy is the drying of the cornea due to the inability to close the eyelids or blink adequately. It can lead to corneal ulceration and perforation, resulting in blindness. Causes include facial nerve palsy, scarring of eyelids, coma, thyroid eye disease, Parkinson's disease, proptosis, and more. Treatment aims to moisten the cornea and prevent complications.

causes.facial_nerve_palsy: Facial nerve palsy e.g. Bell's palsy or leprosy

symptoms: Feeling of drying of the eye
Foreign body sensations in the eye
signs: Incomplete blink (the upper eyelid does not cover the whole cornea during blink)
Superficial punctate stains on the cornea

objectives: To prevent complications of dry eyes
non-pharmacological: Taping the eyelids closed in the comatose patient
Education of patients to blink frequently voluntarily
pharmacological: 1st Line Treatment: Hydroxymethyl cellulose eye drops, Polyvinyl alcohol eye drops, Chloramphenicol eye ointment, Tetracycline eye ointment
referral_criteria: Refer patients whose exposure keratopathy is not improving to the eye specialist

Female Infertility.introduction: Female infertility refers to the inability of a couple to achieve a pregnancy despite at least one year of unprotected sexual intercourse. It can be caused by various factors like ovulation failure, PCOS, pelvic factors, male factors, and more. Treatment aims to treat the underlying cause of infertility if possible and achieve pregnancy.

causes.female_pelvic_factors: Pelvic factors (congenital malformations, tubal disease, pelvic adhesions, uterine fibroids, endometriosis, cervical factors)
causes.male_factors: Male factors (oligospermia, azoospermia, penile and testicular abnormalities, erectile dysfunction)

symptoms: Inability to achieve pregnancy despite regular unprotected sex
investigations: Hormonal studies (to be done by specialist)

objectives: To treat the underlying cause of the infertility if possible
To achieve pregnancy within the shortest possible time
referral_criteria: Early referral of all patients with infertility to a specialist is preferred, particularly women with uterine, ovarian or tubal disease requiring surgery or who require ovulation induction not responsive to clomifene citrate. Also refer male partners for review by a urologist.

Fever.introduction: Fever is a common complaint usually related to infections of viral, bacterial, or parasitic origin. It's defined as an axillary temperature above 37.5°C. Elevated fever above 38°C in children and adults often requires urgent attention. Proper investigation, including history, physical examination, and appropriate tests, can reveal the cause of the fever.
investigations: Cultures of urine, blood, sputum, etc.

objectives: To reduce body temperature to normal
To identify and treat the underlying cause
non-pharmacological: Keep the patient well hydrated with fluids
pharmacological: Treat the cause of the fever appropriately

Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Complaints: Rigors, fever (occasionally periodic), sweating, general malaise, joint pains
Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Action: Take a blood film or perform rapid diagnostic test for malaria parasites and treat appropriately

Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Complaints: Rigors, fever, sweating, general malaise, altered sensorium
Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Action: Take a blood film or perform rapid diagnostic test for malaria parasites and treat appropriately

Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Complaints: Headache, vomiting, drowsiness, stiff neck, seizures
Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Action: Do not delay treatment while awaiting results of lumbar puncture

Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Complaints: Cough, brown sputum, rapid breathing, pain on deep breathing
Increased frequency of urination and/or painful micturition, loin pain
Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Action: Do urine examination plus culture and sensitivity; Give appropriate antibiotic

Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Complaints: Fever, constipation or diarrhoea (may be with blood), headache, abdominal pain, general malaise
Warm, swollen, painful, reddish looking limb
Fever in a child with cough, sore throat and red ear drums
Fever during pregnancy with loin pain
Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Action: Take sample for urine culture and sensitivity and give appropriate antibiotic

Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Complaints: Pain in a bone (usually a limb bone), painful to touch
Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Action: X-ray the affected part; treat as for osteomyelitis

Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Complaints: Jaundice preceded by feeling unwell, anorexia, low-grade fever
Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Action: Do liver function tests, Hepatitis B surface antigen; treat conservatively, bed rest

Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Complaints: Headache, body ache, runny nose, sneezing
Long-standing fever, weight loss, chronic diarrhoea, lymphadenopathy
Sore throat or pain on swallowing
Abrupt fever, chills and malaise; weakness, muscle pain, rash, diarrhoea, bleeding
Fever_Treatment_Guidelines.Diagnosis: Viral haemorrhagic fever e.g. Ebola virus disease

referral_criteria: Fever persisting for more than 10 days despite treatment should be referred for further investigation.

Fibromyalgia.introduction: Fibromyalgia is a disorder of chronic, widespread pain and tenderness. It often occurs in patients with other conditions. While no clear pathophysiological mechanism is established, evidence suggests an abnormality in central pain processing. Treatment includes patient education, stress reduction, exercise, and medications.

pharmacological: Clonazepam with Fluoxetine or Amitriptyline or Duloxetine
referral_criteria: Refer patients not responding to treatment to the appropriate specialist.

Foreign Bodies in the Eye.introduction: Foreign bodies in the eye can cause irritation and discomfort. Proper lighting is necessary to detect corneal foreign bodies. The goal is to remove superficial foreign bodies, treat associated injuries, and prevent complications.
symptoms: Feeling of something in the eye
signs: Irregular pupil or blood in the anterior chamber (penetrating eye injury)
investigations: X-ray of the orbit (suspected metallic foreign body)

non-pharmacological: Evert the eyelid to remove foreign body
REFER to an eye specialist clinic
pharmacological: Tetracaine hydrochloride (eye drop) for foreign body identification
Chloramphenicol eye ointment (after removal of foreign body) for infection prevention
referral_criteria: Refer patients with corneal foreign bodies, intraocular foreign bodies, persistent pain and redness of the eye to the eye specialist.

Fournier's Gangrene.introduction: Fournier's Gangrene is an acute fulminant polymicrobial necrotizing fasciitis affecting the scrotum, perineum, penis, and lower abdomen. It's caused by synergistic infections of anaerobic and aerobic bacteria, often associated with obliterative arteritis. Risk factors include diabetes, HIV, perineal abscess, trauma, and more. Complications include septicemia, urinary extravasation, testes exposure, and fistula formation.
symptoms: Acute onset of painful anterior scrotal swelling
signs: Sharp demarcation between 'dead' and healthy tissue

pharmacological: IV fluids, hemotransfusion, and hyperbaric oxygen
referral_criteria: Refer septic shock cases and those requiring reconstructive surgery to a urologist or surgical specialist.

Poisoning.introduction: Poisoning results from toxic exposure to substances. Mild symptoms may develop, but poisoning should be considered a medical emergency. Supportive care and treatment are critical for preventing deaths. Effects depend on the substance, exposure route, dose, and more. Specific antidotes may be used based on findings.

referral_criteria: Refer patients for specialist management if not improving with supportive care or requiring specific antidotes

Glaucoma.introduction: Glaucoma is an optic neuropathy associated with raised intraocular pressure. It's a major cause of preventable blindness. Chronic glaucoma may cause vision loss without warning, while acute glaucoma is associated with high pressure, severe pain, and inflammation. Congenital glaucoma enlarges the eyeball and increases light sensitivity. Treatment may vary based on local availability and response.
causes: Acute closure of the drainage angle
Malformation of drainage angle in congenital glaucoma

referral_criteria: Refer suspected cases to an ophthalmologist for assessment and initial treatment

Goitre.introduction: A goitre is a swelling of the front of the neck due to enlargement of the thyroid gland. It may be benign or malignant, associated with normal, reduced, or excessive thyroid function. Proper diagnosis is based on clinical assessment and investigations. Treatment is not necessarily by increasing iodine intake. Causes include obesity, hiatus hernia, increased intra-abdominal pressure, long-term use of nasogastric tubes, and more.
causes: Simple non-toxic goitre or endemic goitre

objectives: Assess and correct thyroid hormone production
pharmacological: Appropriate treatment for hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism
referral_criteria: Refer patients to a physician or surgical specialist for complications, malignancy, or complex cases

Gout.introduction: Gout is a condition characterized by the deposition of uric acid crystals in joints and periarticular tissues. It typically causes pain and inflammation in affected joints. Causes include overproduction or impaired excretion of uric acid. Gout flares can be triggered by various factors. Treatment aims to relieve pain, reduce inflammation, and prevent recurrence. Both acute and chronic gout management are covered.
causes: Overproduction of uric acid in disorders
investigations: Serum uric acid, blood glucose, serum lipids
X-ray of affected joint, joint aspirate

objectives: Prevent recurrent attacks and joint damage
referral_criteria: Refer to a dietician, physician specialist, or rheumatologist based on the case

Gastro-oesophageal Reflux Disease (GORD).introduction: GORD is caused by the backflow of gastric and/or duodenal contents past the lower oesophageal sphincter into the oesophagus. It's classified into non-erosive and erosive GORD. Failure to treat may lead to complications such as oesophagitis, ulcers, strictures, and adenocarcinoma. Causes include obesity, hiatus hernia, increased intra-abdominal pressure, and more.
causes: Long term use of nasogastric tube
Agents that decrease lower oesophageal sphincter pressure

pharmacological: Severe or erosive GORD treatment (omeprazole, esomeprazole, rabeprazole)
Severe or erosive GORD with bloating (combination with metoclopramide or domperidone)
referral_criteria: Refer cases not responding or with complications to a physician or surgical specialist

Haematuria.introduction: This is the passage of blood in the urine. It may be microscopic or macroscopic, intermittent or continuous...
causes: Carcinoma of prostate, bladder and kidney
Medical causes e.g. sickle cell disease, acute glomerulonephritis and anticoagulant therapy
symptoms: Fever suggests infection e.g. pyelonephritis, cystitis and prostatitis
Colicky flank pain suggests urinary stones
Associated lower urinary tract symptoms suggest bladder or prostatic cause
Blood in the urine (on initiation, mixed with the urine, or at the end of passing urine)
Pain/discomfort on passing urine usually associated with infection, calculi or trauma
Painless intermittent haematuria associated with cancers eg bladder and kidney cancers
investigations: FBC and sickling status(Hb electrophoresis if sickling test is positive)

non-pharmacological: High fluid intake is advised in order to prevent clot formation in the urinary bladder
If patient presents with clot retention, then catheterize and refer
pharmacological: For Urinary Tract Infection - Give appropriate antibiotics
treatment.referral: Refer all other cases as well as those with persistent haematuria for appropriate investigations and treatment.

Haemorrhoids.introduction: Haemorrhoids or "piles" are enlarged, displaced anal cushions derived from engorged veins...
causes: Increased intra-abdominal pressure e.g. chronic cough, pregnancy, intra-abdominal or pelvic tumours
Excessive straining at stools from constipation or diarrhoea
Chronic liver disease with portal hypertension
symptoms: Passage of bright red blood at defaecation
May spray the toilet bowl or only found on the toilet paper after cleaning
Anal pain (occurs during an acute attack of prolapse with thrombosis, congestion and oedema)

non-pharmacological: Increase intake of fluid and roughage
For prolapsed haemorrhoids, lie patient down and elevate the foot end of the bed...
For infected haemorrhoids, warm sitz baths 2-3 times a day
Surgical treatment: Rubber band ligation for second-degree haemorrhoids...
Haemorrhoids developing during pregnancy should be managed conservatively as most will resolve after delivery
pharmacological: When associated with constipation - Liquid paraffin, oral, or Senna granules, oral
When associated with local itching or discomfort - Soothing agent (with or without steroids), applied or inserted rectally
For infected haemorrhoids - 1st Line treatment: Gentamicin, IV, and Metronidazole, oral...
2nd Line treatment: Ciprofloxacin, oral, and Metronidazole, oral...
3rd Line treatment: Amoxicillin, oral, and Metronidazole, oral...
When associated with anaemia - Iron preparation (ferrous sulphate/fumarate) or Blood transfusion as indicated
treatment.referral: The patient should be referred to a facility with resources for rubber band ligation or operative treatment if indicated.

Soft Tissue Infections of the Hand.introduction: These are emergencies and require early diagnosis and prompt treatment. Staph. spp are responsible for the majority of cases...
causes: Blows to the head (fights, including domestic violence, street fights)
investigations: Gram stain and culture of discharge

objectives: Prevent complications such as stiffness of the joints and septicaemia
pharmacological: For treatment of suspected simple Staph. infections - 1st Line Treatment: Flucloxacillin, oral, or 2nd Line Treatment: Clindamycin, oral...
For treatment of suspected severe Staph. infections - 1st Line Treatment: Cloxacillin, IV, or 2nd Line Treatment: Clindamycin, IV/IM...
For treatment of chronic paronychia - 1st Line Treatment: Itraconazole, oral, or Miconazole tincture, topical...
2nd Line Treatment: Fluconazole, oral, or Clotrimazole, topical...
3rd Line Treatment: Griseofulvin, oral, or Miconazole tincture, topical...
treatment.referral: Refer to appropriate specialists if patient does not improve.

Head Injuries.introduction: These are injuries in which the scalp, skull, meninges, brain, or the blood vessels within the brain may be affected separately or together...
causes: Blows to the head (fights, including domestic violence, street fights)
symptoms: Leakage of clear fluid or bleeding from the ears or nostrils
investigations: Cranial CT scan or MRI if warranted

objectives: To prevent further injury to the brain
To prevent complications relating to the underlying cause
non-pharmacological: Assess level of consciousness and provide appropriate treatment
Maintain a clear airway, suck out any secretions and assist ventilation if necessary
Maintain the blood pressure (if patient hypotensive or hypertensive)
Nurse with head end of bed elevated
Stabilize the neck with a collar till cervical spine injury has been excluded
If patient is unconscious, turn every 2 hours
Pass nasogastric tube for feeding if patient is unconscious. Do not pass nasogastric tube if there is suspected fracture of the skull base
pharmacological: For lowering of raised intracranial pressure - Mannitol 20%, IV, or Hypertonic saline 3%, IV...
For mild pain management - Paracetamol, oral, or Diclofenac, oral...
For fracture base of skull - Cloxacillin, IV, or Benzylpenicillin, IV...
For open skull fractures - Amoxicillin + Clavulanic Acid, IV, and Metronidazole, IV...
For aggressive patients requiring sedation - Haloperidol, IM, or Lorazepam, IV/IM...
treatment.referral: Refer all patients with significant head injuries immediately to a neurosurgeon.

Headache.introduction: Headache is caused by traction, displacement, inflammation, vascular spasm or distension of the pain sensitive structures in the head or neck...
symptoms: Visual e.g. photophobia, flashes of light, floaters
Aura e.g. visual, auditory, gustatory, tactile
Accompanying features e.g. nausea, vomiting, fever, collapse
Site of pain e.g. occipital, ocular, unilateral, bilateral
Characteristics e.g. pulsating, throbbing, sharp, dull
Relieving or exacerbating factors e.g. cough, coitus, lying flat
investigations: Cranial CT scan or MRI if warranted

objectives: To identify and treat underlying cause
To prevent complications relating to the underlying cause
non-pharmacological: Identification and elimination of trigger factors
pharmacological: Acute symptomatic treatment of headaches - Paracetamol, oral, or Diclofenac, oral, or Ibuprofen, oral, or Tramadol, oral
Prophylaxis for Migraine headaches - Propranolol, oral
treatment.referral: Refer recurrent, unresolving or unexplained headaches to a specialist for evaluation and appropriate management.

Heart Failure.introduction: This is a condition in which the heart is unable to produce adequate cardiac output...
symptoms: Swelling of the feet and lower extremities
Right hypochondrial pain from an enlarging liver
investigations: Blood urea, electrolytes and creatinine and eGFR
Cardiac enzymes, if myocardial infarction is suspected

objectives: To relieve symptoms and improve quality of life
To reduce need for hospital re-admissions
non-pharmacological: Reduce weight in overweight and obese individuals
Bed rest (only in acute heart failure or exacerbations of chronic heart failure)

Haemophilus Influenzae type b Disease.introduction: The Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) bacterium is an important cause of infections such as acute bacterial meningitis...
symptoms: Other symptoms associated with pneumonia, otitis media, meningitis, septicaemia
investigations: Culture and sensitivity of appropriate body fluids

non-pharmacological: Treat based on the presenting illness e.g. meningitis, pneumonia
treatment.pharmacological: Treat based on the presenting illness e.g. meningitis, pneumonia
treatment.referral: Refer patients if the condition does not improve. All children with hepatic encephalopathy must be referred to a specialist.

Hepatic Encephalopathy.introduction: This condition is a complication of either acute or chronic liver disease. It presents with disordered central nervous system function...
causes: Drugs e.g. halothane, isoniazid, paracetamol overdose, herbal preparations
Precipitating factors in a patient with pre-existing liver disease

To treat underlying cause of liver disease

Monitor temperature, pulse and respiratory rate, blood pressure, pupils, urine output and blood glucose regularly
Avoid alcohol, paracetamol and other hepatotoxic agents
Avoid sedatives such as benzodiazepines and drugs that impair the coagulation system
Encourage intake of high carbohydrate diet by mouth or NG tube

Dextrose saline (5-10% dextrose in 0.9% saline), IV
Measures to lower blood ammonia concentration - 1st Line Treatment:

Hepatocellular Carcinoma.introduction: Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) is a primary malignancy of the liver cell...
causes: Chronic exposure to hepatic carcinogens e.g. aflatoxin
symptoms: Feeling of a mass in the upper abdomen
signs: Hepatomegaly (irregular surface, multiple nodules, may be tender)

non-pharmacological: Surgical resection of non-metastatic localised lesions
pharmacological: Pain control in patients with Hepatocellular Carcinoma - 1st Line Treatment:
treatment.referral: Refer all patients with suspected HCC, especially those with small solitary lesion (< 5 cm) who may be considered for percutaneous alcohol injection or surgical resection, to a specialist.

Herpes Simplex Infections.introduction: These are acute self-limiting viral infections of the skin and mucous membranes resulting in blistering eruptions...
symptoms: Tingling, discomfort, or painful sensation over affected skin area

objectives: To limit extent of disease spread in the immunocompromised and atopic eczema patients
pharmacological: Perioral or genital lesions - Aciclovir cream 5%, topical:
Adults - 4 hourly (five times daily) for 4-5 days
Children - 4 hourly (five times daily) for 4-5 days
Severe primary infections, disseminated herpes simplex, frequent recurrences and immunosuppressed patients:
Adults - 400 mg 4 hourly (five times daily) for 5-7 days
Children - >2 years; 200 mg 4 hourly (five times daily) for 5-7 days
Adults - 500 mg-1 g 6-8 hourly for 3-5 days
Children - 6-12 years; 250-500 mg 6-8 hourly for 3-5 days
3 months-1 year; 60-120 mg 6-8 hourly for 3-5 days
treatment.referral: Refer complicated cases to a dermatologist.

Herpes Zoster.introduction: This is an acute painful blistering viral infection of the skin...
signs: Tender vesicles spread within one or more dermatomes unilaterally
investigations: HIV screen (for recurrence and/or multi-dermatomal cases)

objectives: To limit extent of disease spread in immuno-compromised patients
pharmacological: Mild Herpes Zoster Infection - Aciclovir cream 5%, topical:
Adults - 4 hourly (five times daily) for 4-5 days

Severe Herpes Zoster Infection - Aciclovir, oral:

treatment.referral: Refer complicated cases to a specialist.

Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AID.introduction: Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) is a late stage of infection with the Human Immune Deficiency Virus (HIV). It can affect both adults and children...
signs: Chronic progressive and disseminated herpes simplex infections (adults)
Finger nail changes e.g. blue discoloration of the nails (adults)
Failure to thrive or slow growth (infants and children)
Recurrent common infections e.g. otitis media, pharyngitis (infants and children)
investigations: Confirmatory HIV test (HIV1, HIV2, HIV1 and 2)
Other tests as required (See Table 17-1 on page)

objectives: To suppress HIV replication to as low as possible and for as long as possible
To preserve and enhance the immune function (CD4 restoration)
To reduce morbidity and mortality related to HIV
To promote growth and neurological development in children.
treatment.referral: Refer all HIV positive patients to an accredited treatment centre in Ghana.

Post-exposure Prophylaxis (PEP).introduction: Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is short-term antiretroviral treatment to reduce the likelihood of HIV infection...
causes: An exposure considered as possible risk is defined as "an exposure from possibly infected blood tissue or other body fluids...
The risk of infection appears to be higher after:
Exposure to a large quantity of blood or to other infectious fluids
Exposure to the blood of a patient in an advanced HIV disease stage.
A deep percutaneous injury or an injury with a hollow bore, blood filled needle.
investigations: HIV serology or PCR if available

objectives: To prevent establishment of HIV infection
non-pharmacological: Exposed health workers must receive counselling and testing immediately from a trained counsellor. The session is to continue throughout the PEP period and thereafter if necessary. Refusal of HIV test by any exposed worker should be documented
Counsellor must emphasize safe sex including condom use.
All known source-patients shall also be counselled and tested for HIV infection if this is not known.
pharmacological: Note 17-1 Timing: If PEP is necessary, it should be initiated promptly, preferably within 1-2 hours post-exposure and not more than 72 hours after exposure.
Evidence Rating: [A] A. Very Low Risk - Wash exposed area immediately with soap and water
B. Low Risk - Tenofovir 300 mg daily for 28 days And Emtricitabine 200 mg daily for 28 days Or Zidovudine 300 mg 12 hourly for 28 days And Lamivudine 150 mg 12 hourly for 28 days

C. High Risk - Tenofovir 300 mg daily for 28 days And Emtricitabine 200 mg daily for 28 days And Lopinavir/r 400 mg/100 mg 12 hourly for 28 days Or Zidovudine 300 mg 12 hourly for 28 days And Lamivudine 150 mg 12 hourly for 28 days And Lopinavir/r 400 mg/100 mg 12 hourly for 28 days
Note 17-2 - If the source patient is HIV/HBV co-infected then a Tenofovir containing regimen should be used.
Follow up - During the period of prophylaxis, a number of baseline and follow-up investigations need to be done to determine HIV serostatus, and to monitor the level of drug toxicity.
Individuals who seroconvert should have access to comprehensive care and ART services.
Box 17-2: Reporting and Documentation - All occupational exposures should be reported immediately to the supervisor; circumstances of the exposure and PEP management should be recorded.

Preferred Regimen.caution: Caution with Tenofovir in renal dysfunction

Alternative Regimen.caution: Caution with Tenofovir in renal dysfunction
Alternative Regimen.comment: Nevirapine is contraindicated in liver dysfunction and NVP hypersensitivity. Monitor renal function including urinalysis. Stop NVP if client develops jaundice or severe rashes and refer to ART centre for further management.

Alternative Regimen.caution: Zidovudine is contraindicated in severe anaemia. Nevirapine is contraindicated in liver dysfunction and NVP hypersensitivity.
Alternative Regimen.comment: TDF to be used where Hb is < 8 g/dL or drops >25% from the baseline value in a client on AZT. Stop NVP if client develops jaundice or severe rashes and refer to ART centre for further management.

Alternative Regimen.comment: TDF to be used where Hb is < 8 g/dL or drops >25% from the baseline value in a client on AZT.
