If ZDV based first line. Consider Abacavir if patient has used both Tenofovir and Zidovudine

HIV co-infection with Hepatitis B. (See.recommendation: The recommended regimen shall be: Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Efavirenz
HIV co-infection with Hepatitis B. (See.comment: Lamivudine and Tenofovir are active against both HBV and HIV

Dual HIV-1 and HIV-2 or HIV-2 infections.recommendation: Due to the ineffectiveness of non-nucleoside drugs (Nevirapine and Efavirenz) in HIV-2 infection combination of nucleosides and protease inhibitors such as LPVr or ATV/r should be used.

Pediatric Cyanotic Heart Attack.introduction: This is a life threatening paediatric cardiac emergency. It usually occurs in infants with a peak incidence between 4 and 6 months...
causes: Congenital heart disease e.g. Tetralogy of Fallot, pulmonary stenosis, double outlet right ventricle, tricuspid atresia, Eisenmenger syndrome

objectives: To correct metabolic derangement in severe hypoxia
To prevent complications and death from severe hypoxia
non-pharmacological: Hold in knee chest position (teach parents)
The above actions increase peripheral vascular resistance and help to reduce cyanosis.

A. All children with hypercyanotic attac: Oxygen (100%), by face mask or nasal prongs, 2 L/minute (monitoring oxygen saturation if possible) - to all patients to reduce hypoxia
0.9% Normal Saline or Ringers' Lactate, IV, 10 ml/kg, over 30 minutes then assess response
Morphine sulphate, slow IV (preferred), or IM, if IV line not accessible, 100-200 micrograms/kg stat.
B. For patients with poor response to ab: Children 1 month-12 years 500 microgram/kg 8 hourly (max. 5 mg/kg daily)
D. Maintenance treatment to prevent recu: Children 1 month-12 years 0.25-1 mg/kg 6-8 hourly (max. 5 mg/kg daily)
Propranolol, slow IV with ECG monitoring: Children 1 month-12 years 15-20 microgram/kg 6-8 hourly (max. 200 microgram/kg) repeated every 6-8 hours if necessary
Neonates 15-20 microgram/kg (max. 100 microgram/kg) repeated every 12 hours if necessary

treatment.referral: Hypercyanotic attack is an indication for early surgery. Refer urgently to a paediatric specialist or cardiothoracic surgeon

Hyperemesis Gravidarum.introduction: This refers to excessive vomiting usually during the early part of pregnancy, and is usually common...
symptoms: Excessive vomiting (sometimes with inability to keep anything down throughout the day)
Inability to eat or drink (due to fear of vomiting)
signs: Dehydration (dry skin, dry tongue, sunken eyes in extreme cases)
The pulse is rapid and thready in extreme cases
Deep and fast breathing in extreme cases

objectives: To treat associated conditions e.g. UTI, malaria
non-pharmacological: Mild cases can have treatment at home with frequent small meals
Dry foods such as biscuits may be very helpful
Drink fluids in sips or small volumes, if able to

Severe Cases: Normal saline, IV, (alternate with 5% Dextrose to meet requirements)
Ringers lactate, IV, (alternate with 5% Dextrose to meet requirements)
Metoclopramide, IM or IV, 5-10 mg 8 hourly
If body weight < 60 kg, give 5 mg 8 hourly. Do not exceed 500 microgram/kg in a day
Ondansetron, oral, IM, IV, 4-8 mg 8 hourly as needed
Promethazine hydrochloride, IM or IV, 25 mg 8-12 hourly (max. daily dose, 100 mg)

treatment.referral: Refer severe cases with dehydration and/or shock and metabolic disturbances to a hospital for intravenous fluid replacement and antiemetic therapy.

Hypertension.introduction: Hypertension or 'high blood pressure' carries an increased risk of early death from stroke, heart attack, heart failure...

objectives: To reduce blood pressure levels to recommended targets...
To manage co-morbid conditions e.g. obesity, diabetes, lipids etc.
To prevent cardiovascular, cerebrovascular and renal complications
To promote therapeutic lifestyle changes e.g. smoking cessation, regular physical activity, reduction in alcohol intake
To identify and manage secondary hypertension appropriately
non-pharmacological: Ensure regular fruit and vegetable intake
Weight reduction in obese and overweight individuals
Regular exercise e.g. brisk walking for 30 minutes 3 times a week

1st Line Treatment: Thiazide Diuretics: Bendroflumethiazide, oral, 2.5 mg daily
Or Hydrochlorothiazide, oral, 12.5 mg-25 mg daily
And/Or Calcium Channel Blockers: Amlodipine, oral, 5-10 mg daily
Or Nifedipine retard, oral, 10-40 mg 12 hourly
And/Or Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors: Lisinopril, oral, 5-40 mg daily
Or Angiotensin receptor blockers: Losartan, oral, 25-100 mg daily
And/Or Beta-blockers: Atenolol, oral, 50 -100 mg daily
2nd Line Treatment: Centrally acting agents: Methyldopa, oral, 250 mg-1g 8-12 hourly
And/Or Vasodilators: Hydralazine, oral, 25-50 mg 12 hourly
And/Or Alpha-blockers: Prazosin, oral, 0.5 mg 8-12 hourly and increasing gradually to a max. dose of 20 mg
And/Or Aldosterone antagonists: Spironolactone, oral, 25-50 mg daily

treatment.referral: Refer the following categories of hypertensive patients to an appropriate specialist...

Hypertension in Children.introduction: Hypertension in children is defined as an average systolic and/or diastolic blood pressure that is 2" 95th percentile...
causes: eat too much salt and do not eat enough fruit and vegetables
drink too much alcohol or coffee (or other caffeine-based drinks)
signs: blurred vision or other vision changes
investigations: serum levels of potassium, sodium, creatinine, blood glucose, and total cholesterol and triglycerides

objectives: To reduce blood pressure (BP) to a target of < 95th percentile...
To encourage weight reduction in obese and overweight children
non-pharmacological: Therapeutic lifestyle changes: weight control, regular exercise, low-fat intake, low sodium diet, regular fruit and vegetable intake
pharmacological: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors: Enalapril, oral, Children...
Calcium channel blockers: Nifedipine, oral, Children...
treatment.referral: Refer all cases of hypertension in children to a specialist for investigation and further treatment.

Hypertension in Pregnancy.introduction: Hypertension in pregnancy denotes a systolic blood pressure of 140 mmHg or higher and/or diastolic pressure of 90 mmHg...
investigations: Chest CT scan with angiography (for suspected aortic dissection)
Cardiac enzymes:creatinine kinase-MB (CK-MB), serum aspartate, transaminase (AST), serum lactic dehydrogenase (LDH) and troponins (for acute coronary syndrome)

objectives: To detect or treat any complications that may arise especially super imposed pre-eclampsia

Hypertension in Pregnancy not associated: Nifedipine sustained release, oral, 10-40 mg 12 hourly

treatment.repeat_intervals: Repeat at 10 minute intervals, if necessary, to a max. of 200 mg

treatment.referral: Refer all cases of super-imposed pre-eclampsia or other obstetric complication promptly to a hospital or obstetrician after initiation of treatment.

Hypertensive Crisis.introduction: A severe and potentially life-threatening increase in blood pressures (BP) which may result in various complications.
Investigations: Chest CT scan with angiography (for suspected aortic dissection)

Objectives: Limit further organ-related complications by controlled reduction of BP
Control and prevent seizures if present
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer all patients to a physician specialist for further evaluation

Hyperthyroidism.introduction: Excess thyroid hormone in the blood resulting in hyperthyroidism (thyrotoxicosis) with potential complications.

Objectives: Reduce thyroid hormone levels to normal
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer all cases not responding to conventional treatment to specialists for further management

Hypothyroidism.introduction: Reduction in thyroid hormone production with potential developmental and health consequences.
Symptoms: Poor growth, development, and school performance in children
Signs: Various signs across neonates, children, and adults

Objectives: Correct blood level of thyroid hormones
Maintain lifelong normal levels of thyroid hormones
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer diagnosed or suspected cases to a specialist

Idiopathic Inflammatory Myopathies.introduction: Systemic connective tissue diseases characterized by muscle weakness, chronic inflammation, and more.
Symptoms: Trouble climbing stairs, getting up from a seat, or reaching for objects overhead
Signs: Various signs including muscle weakness and specific skin manifestations

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer all patients to a physician specialist or rheumatologist

Immunisation.introduction: Immunisation against vaccine preventable diseases through the national Expanded Programme for Immunisation (EPI) is one of the most effective measures for reducing morbidity and mortality.
Immunisation.Schedule: Routine Immunisation schedule for children under 5 years of age and immunisation of preterm babies.

Contraindications.Various Contraindications: Current serious febrile illness, severe reaction history, evolving neurological disease, convulsions or active CNS disease, history of anaphylaxis with egg ingestion, symptomatic HIV infection
Contraindications.Exception: Measles vaccine can be given to HIV positive patients

Immunisation.Referral Criteria: Refer all problems related to Immunisation to a paediatrician or EPI specialist.

Impetigo.introduction: Highly contagious superficial bacterial skin infection commonly affecting neonates and children.
Symptoms: Pus-filled blisters and sores on the body or scalp
Signs: Irregular spreading ulcers with yellow crusts
Investigations: Microscopy and culture of exudate from blisters

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer for hospital care and treatment if spreading rapidly or complications develop.

Insomnia.introduction: Subjective difficulty with sleep initiation, duration, consolidation, or quality resulting in daytime impairment.
Symptoms: Total sleep time less than 6.5 hours
Daytime fatigue, sleepiness, mood disturbances, cognitive difficulties
Investigations: Various blood tests including FBC, BUE, creatinine, LFTs, blood glucose, thyroid function tests

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer to clinical psychologist for patients not responding to common interventions and to appropriate specialists for underlying causes.

Ischaemic Heart Disease.introduction: Condition with reduced blood supply to the heart muscle, including stable angina pectoris and acute coronary syndromes.

Stable Angina Pectoris.introduction: Chest pain induced by exertion or stress, relieved by rest or glyceryl trinitrate.
Causes: Atherosclerosis with narrowing of coronary vessels
Stable Angina Pectoris.Symptoms: Central or precordial chest pain, may radiate to arm, neck, jaw; relieved by rest or glyceryl trinitrate

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer if symptoms don't improve or risk factors worsen

Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS).introduction: Symptoms from severe acute myocardial ischaemia, classified as STEMI or NSTEMI/unstable angina.
Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS).Symptoms: Chest pain, sudden onset, may radiate; nausea, vomiting, shortness of breath, fatigue; loss of consciousness

Treatment.Non-pharmacological: Bed rest, cessation of smoking, weight reduction

Pharmacological.Initial Treatment: Oxygen, aspirin, clopidogrel, glyceryl trinitrate, morphine, metoclopramide
Pharmacological.Maintenance Treatment: Aspirin, clopidogrel, anticoagulation, beta blockers, ACE inhibitors/ARBs
Pharmacological.Complications Management: Pulmonary oedema, cardiogenic shock, cardiac arrhythmias
Pharmacological.Long-term Treatment: Aspirin, beta blockers, ACE inhibitors/ARBs, statins, isosorbide dinitrate

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Urgent ECG for suspected ACS, refer confirmed STEMI patients urgently

Jaundice.introduction: Yellow pigmentation of skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin levels in blood.
Symptoms: Yellow or greenish discolouration of eyes or skin

Jaundice in Pregnancy.introduction: Jaundice occurring in pregnancy as a symptom or sign of a severe disease.

Non-obstetric: Haemolytic conditions: malaria, sickle cell disease, G6PD defect, septicaemia, drugs, and herbal medications
Surgical causes: acute cholecystitis, cholelithiasis, obstructive jaundice

Symptoms: Other symptoms relating to the cause
Signs: Yellow discoloration of mucous membranes and skin
Liver enlargement (If associated with liver disease)
Other signs relating to the cause
Investigations: FBC, blood film for malaria parasites, RDT
Abdominal ultrasound scan (focus on hepato-biliary system and pancreas)

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Severe cases and those with abdominal pain should be referred for specialist care.

Local Anaesthetics.introduction: Local anaesthetic agents used for anaesthesia and analgesia, their administration, effects, and treatment of toxicity.

Lidocaine (Lignocaine).Notes: Lidocaine is not recommended for spinal anaesthesia.

Bupivacaine.Maximum Dose: 2 mg/kg (for both plain and with adrenaline added)
Bupivacaine.Caution: Bupivacaine should be used with caution. Intralipid 20% is effective for treating cardiotoxicity.

Uses: Intravenous preparation of lignocaine used as an antiarrhythmic
Prevention of Local Anaesthetic Toxicity: Always aspirate before injecting to prevent inadvertent intravascular injection
Do not inject large volumes at a time
Caution when injecting into areas of high vascularity
Symptoms and Signs of Local Anaesthesia: Altered consciousness, seizures, loss of consciousness, respiratory arrest

Treatment of Local Anaesthetic Toxicity.Stop Injection of LA: Start ABC (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) of resuscitation
Treat Seizures: Give Midazolam (3-5 mg) or diazepam (5-10 mg) to treat seizures
If seizures persist, an anaesthetist can give thiopentone 1-2 mg/kg or more midazolam and paralyse, intubate, and ventilate patient
Treat Cardiovascular Instability: For bupivacaine or ropivacaine use, give Intralipid 20%

Intralipid Use: Initial bolus of Intralipid 20%, 1.5 ml/kg fast
Start infusion of 20% Intralipid at 0.25 ml/kg/min
Repeat initial bolus twice at 5-minute intervals if adequate circulation is not restored
Maximum dose of 12 ml/kg of Intralipid 20% should not be exceeded

Treatment of Local Anaesthetic Toxicity.Cardiac Arrest: Start CPR and call for help

Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis.introduction: Results from abnormally regulated immune responses that lead to inflammation of joints, surrounding tissues, and other organs. Non-rheumatic diseases with similar features need to be excluded during evaluation.

Types.Poly-articular Onset Arthritis: Affects 5 or more joints, may be rheumatoid factor positive or negative.
Types.Others: Positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA) test requires regular eye checks for uveitis.
Types.Diagnosis Duration: Arthritis must be present for at least 6 weeks for diagnosis.

Signs.Red eyes: Yellow discoloration of mucous membranes and skin.

Investigations: Other tests as determined by specialist

Objectives: Optimize chance for normal social development

Control Pain and Inflammation.1st Line Treatment: Ibuprofen, oral, Children: Dosing based on age
Control Pain and Inflammation.2nd Line Treatment: Celecoxib, oral, Children: Dosing based on weight
Control Pain and Inflammation.Caution: Long-term use of NSAIDs may cause renal impairment and gastritis. Refer after two weeks of use.
Control Pain and Inflammation.Steroid Therapy: Prednisolone, oral, Children: Dosing based on weight. Consider chronic case if no improvement after 6 weeks.

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer all suspected cases to a pediatrician or rheumatologist.

Large Chronic Ulcers.introduction: An ulcer or sore that breaches the continuity of the skin and underlying tissue. Can lead to serious complications, including deformity, joint ankylosis, osteomyelitis, cellulitis, and malignant transformation.

Causes.Infections and Infestations: e.g. Buruli ulcers, yaws ulcers, tuberculous ulcers, guinea worm ulcers
Causes.Non-specific Ulcers: e.g. pressure (decubitus), traumatic, venous, diabetic, sickle cell ulcers, ischemic
Causes.Malignant Ulcers: e.g. squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma, Kaposi's sarcoma

Symptoms: Loss of sensation at site of ulcer

Others: Loss of sensation in affected part
Darkening of affected area (peripheral vascular disease, venous insufficiency)
Pink granulation tissue without slough (healthy wound)

Investigations: Wound swab for culture and sensitivity, Ziehl Nielsen staining

Objectives: Deslough the ulcer and promote healthy granulation tissue formation
Non-Pharmacological Treatment: Use absorbent dressing for wounds with profuse discharge

Wound Cleansing.Non-Antiseptic: Normal saline solution (Do not use Eusol)

Systemic Antibiotic Treatment.Specific Treatment: Guided by culture and sensitivity results
Systemic Antibiotic Treatment.Empiric Treatment: Based on suspected or likely organisms while awaiting results

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer patients with ulcers failing to show signs of healing, requiring surgery, or suspected malignancy to a surgical specialist.

Leukaemia.introduction: Cancer of the blood cells. Two main types: lymphoid leukaemia and myeloid leukaemia. Classifications include acute and chronic. Four main types: ALL, CLL, AML, CML. Different age and gender patterns.

Causes.Unknown: Associated factors include viruses, chemicals, drugs, and ionizing radiation

Acute Leukaemia: Bone and joint pain (especially in children)

Chronic Leukaemia: Generalized lymph node enlargement in CLL

Investigations: LP for CSF cytology (especially in acute lymphoid leukaemia)

Objectives: Aim for cure in ALL in children and adults
Achieve remission and prolong quality life in AML
Aim for haematological remission/cure in philadelphia positive CML
Control white cell counts, symptoms, and quality of life in philadelphia negative CML
Provide supportive treatment (pain relief, transfusion support, treat infections, counseling)
Non-Pharmacological Treatment: Ensure good nutrition and food hygiene
Ensure good oral and personal hygiene

Supportive Treatment: Packed red cells transfusion and platelet transfusion when indicated

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer all patients to a hematologist at a specialized tertiary center for confirmation of diagnosis and start of management.

Local Anaesthetic Agents.introduction: Local anaesthetic (LA) agents block nerve transmission and are used for anaesthesia and analgesia in specific areas of the body. Adrenaline is added to prolong their action.
Local Anaesthetic Agents.Mechanism of Action: Reversibly block nerve transmission, affecting sensory and motor nerves.
Local Anaesthetic Agents.Motor Weakness: Local anaesthetics affect motor nerves, leading to motor weakness depending on application site.

Adrenaline Addition.Concentration: Usual concentration of adrenaline added is 1:200,000.
Adrenaline Addition.Caution: Avoid use in areas with end arteries (e.g., digital nerve blocks), contraindicated in intravenous regional anaesthesia.

Lignocaine (Lidocaine).Maximum Dose: Plain lidocaine: 3 mg/kg (adult approx. 200 mg), with adrenaline: 7 mg/kg.

Uses: Intravenous preparation of lignocaine used as an antiarrhythmic

Guidelines: Avoid injecting large volumes at a time

Treatment: Treat cardiovascular instability with IV fluids and inotropes
Use Intralipid 20% in case of cardiotoxicity

Chronic Periodontal Infections.introduction: Chronic periodontal infections result from prolonged bacterial infection around teeth, causing destruction of supporting tissue.
Investigations: X-ray of involved teeth and supporting tissues

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer all patients to a dental specialist.

Lung Abscess.introduction: Lung abscess is necrosis of lung tissue due to microbial infection. Antibiotic treatment is essential.

Infection Sources: Aspiration of infected secretions or tissue
Staphylococcus aureus causing multiple lung abscesses
Infected bullae in chronic lung disease

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer to a specialist or higher-level facility if there is no clinical improvement.

Malaria.Description: Malaria is a common infection in Ghana, introduced by protozoan malaria parasites from infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. It's a major cause of morbidity and mortality, particularly among vulnerable groups. Cases are categorized as 'uncomplicated' or 'severe'. Diagnosis relies on laboratory tests like blood films or Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDT) since symptoms can overlap with other diseases.
Malaria.Diagnosis_Shift: Diagnosis is moving from clinical to laboratory confirmation for treatment. RDT may be used when microscopy isn't available.
Malaria.Preventive_Measures: Preventive measures target vector elimination or mosquito bite prevention, with added chemoprophylaxis for vulnerable individuals.
Malaria.Resistance_Concern: Malaria parasite resistance to anti-malarial drugs is a concern due to over-diagnosis, wrong diagnosis, and partial treatment. Artemisinin Combination Therapy (ACT) is recommended for uncomplicated malaria.
Malaria.Diagnosis_Principle: Laboratory confirmation is essential for treatment. Exceptions: children under 5 and suspected severe malaria cases.
Causes: Plasmodium falciparum (commonest, responsible for most deaths and morbidity in Ghana)

Symptoms: Irritability and refusal to feed (in infants)
Investigations: Microscopy - thick and thin blood films for malaria parasites

NonPharmacological.Tepid_Sponging: In children, tepid sponging to reduce body temperature

Severe_Malaria.Description: Severe or 'complicated malaria' can result from delayed diagnosis or inappropriate treatment of uncomplicated malaria. It's common in children under 5, pregnant women, and non-immune individuals. Major causes of death in severe malaria include cerebral involvement, severe anemia, hypoglycemia, dehydration, renal failure, and respiratory acidosis. Diagnosis is based on clinical features and confirmed through testing. Immediate treatment is essential even before confirmation.
Symptoms: Poor oral intake (e.g. breast milk in children)
Generalized weakness, inability to walk or sit without assistance
Altered consciousness (change of behavior, confusion, delirium, coma)
Signs: Circulatory collapse or shock (cold limbs, weak rapid pulse)
Spontaneous unexplained heavy bleeding (disseminated intravascular coagulation)
Investigations: Blood film for malaria parasites - thick and thin blood films
Lumbar puncture in convulsing or comatose patients

Objectives: Urgent treatment for life-threatening complications or conditions

NonPharmacological.Positioning: Place unconscious or seizing patients in a safe position to prevent aspiration

Malaria in Pregnancy.introduction: Malaria during pregnancy is severe and can harm both mother and fetus. Preventive measures and proper treatment are crucial.

Male Infertility.introduction: Infertility is the failure to achieve conception within 12 months of unprotected coitus. Male factors contribute significantly to infertility.

Causes.Symptoms: Complaints about wife's inability to conceive, history of STIs, UTIs, surgeries, injuries

Investigations: Evaluation of female partner by gynaecologist

Non-Pharmacological: Avoiding heat, cold, chemicals, tight underwear
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer cases requiring special investigation, treatment to specialist.

Lymphomas.introduction: Lymphomas are disorders characterized by malignant proliferation of lymphoid tissue. Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) are major types.
Lymphomas.Incidence: HL bimodal peak, NHL increases with age and immunosuppression.

Burkitt's Lymphoma.Presentation: Jaw swelling with tooth loosening, common in childhood, peak incidence 4-7 years, male preponderance

Etiological Agents: Chronic antigenic stimulation (H. pylori in gastric lymphoma)

Lymph Node Examination: Superior vena cava syndrome (bulky mediastinal masses)

Investigations: Chest X-ray, abdominal USG, CT scan
Bone marrow aspirate and trephine biopsy

Objectives: Provide supportive treatment (pain relief, transfusion support, infection treatment, counselling)

Pharmacological.Specific Treatment: Available at specialized tertiary centres only
Pharmacological.Referral Criteria: Refer all patients to a haematologist at a specialized tertiary centre

Malnutrition.introduction: Malnutrition results from a deficiency in essential nutrients, commonly seen in children under 5 and associated with increased disease susceptibility.

Marasmus: Hanging skin folds, especially over buttocks
Kwashiorkor: Flaky skin rash, sores on oedematous parts

Investigations: Gastric lavage for acid fast bacilli
Screen for common infections (e.g., tuberculosis, pneumonia)

Objectives: Identify and treat infections and complications
Correct fluid, electrolyte imbalances and deficiencies
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer to appropriate specialist for underlying cause management and family planning services.

Hot Swollen Joint.introduction: Hot swollen joint has various differential diagnoses, including septic arthritis and acute leukemia in children.
Hot Swollen Joint.Common Affected Joint: Big toe, often due to gout
Hot Swollen Joint.Diagnosis: Clinical, especially in the absence of fever
Treatment Objectives: Reduce pain and swelling
Prevent deformities
Delay disease progression and complications
Hot Swollen Joint.Referral Criteria: Refer to orthopedic surgeon or rheumatologist for acutely swollen joint.

Measles.introduction: Measles is an acute infectious disease affecting children, prevented by vaccination. It is highly contagious and can lead to various complications.
Treatment Objectives: Relieve symptoms
Maintain nutrition
Prevent and treat complications
Non-Pharmacological Treatment: Fever management, oral hygiene, feeding, eye wash

administration.2-12 years: 15 mg/kg body weight for 5-7 days (max. 250 mg 12 hourly)
administration.3 months-2 years: 10 mg/kg body weight for 5-7 days (max. 125 mg 12 hourly)

Measles.Referral Criteria: Refer patients with complications to the hospital.

Medicines and the Kidney.introduction: Medicines can lead to renal damage through various mechanisms. Caution is needed to avoid renal impairment, especially in patients with deteriorating renal function.
Medicines and the Kidney.Causes: Polypharmacy, inappropriate medications, underutilization of appropriate medication, transitions in care settings

Management.Treatment Objectives: Prevent Adverse Drug Events (ADE), educate patients, proper drug history, quality prescribing, monitor side effects and interactions, involve patients and maintain accurate medication list
Management.Non-Pharmacological Treatment: Tepid sponging, airway clearance, nasogastric tube feeding

Pharmacological Treatment.Role of Steroids: Dexamethasone, IV, 4-10 mg 6 hourly for 5-7 days

Prescribing for Older Patients.introduction: Prescribing for older patients requires special caution due to age-related changes in drug metabolism and effects. Multi-morbidity and polypharmacy increase the risk of adverse effects.
Principles of Rational Drug Prescribing: Consider ADE as cause of symptoms
Start with one medication at lowest dose

Meningitis.introduction: Meningitis is an infection of the brain coverings. It is usually caused by bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa, and presents with fever, neck stiffness, headache, and altered consciousness.

Pharmacological Treatment.Role of Steroids: Dexamethasone, IV, 4-10 mg 6 hourly for 5-7 days

Menopause.introduction: Menopause is the cessation of menstruation due to ovarian function loss. It may be associated with physical and emotional symptoms, and risks of osteoporosis and cardiovascular disease.
Menopause.Causes: Natural aging, surgical removal of ovaries, pelvic irradiation, premature ovarian failure, pituitary damage, cytotoxic therapy

Pharmacological Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer osteoporosis or severe unremitting symptoms to specialist

Mouth Ulcers.introduction: Mouth ulcers can result from various causes, including infections, neutropenia, malignancy, or trauma. They may be apthous or viral ulcers.

Apthous Ulcers.introduction: Recurrent non-viral ulcers on movable oral surfaces, classified into minor, major, or herpetiform based on size.
Causes: Associated with systemic conditions (Behcet's syndrome, HIV, Vitamin deficiency states)

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer if ulcer doesn't heal within 2 weeks

Urethral Discharge and Dysuria.Investigations: Urethral swab culture and sensitivity (if available)

Intramuscular Quinine in Adults.Dosage Calculation: 10 mg/kg body weight of Quinine given 8 hourly by deep IM injection, to a maximum dose of 600 mg. Small adults (weighing less than 60 kg) should be weighed to calculate the correct dose. Larger adults will simply receive the maximum dose (600 mg). If the required volume is more than 5 ml, divide it into two and inject at separate sites.

Pharmacological treatment.Parenteral antimalarials and follow-on t: The current recommendation is to give parenteral antimalarials in the treatment of severe malaria for a minimum of 24 hours (irrespective of the patient's ability to tolerate oral medication) until the patient is able to tolerate oral medication as follow-on treatment. Recommended follow-on treatments include ACTs and Quinine + clindamycin.
Treatment in Referral Centre: Artesunate, IV or IM, ADULTS and CHILDREN > 20 kg: 2.4 mg/kg 12 hourly Given at time 0 hour (i.e. on admission), at 12 hours and 24 hours Then 2.4 mg/kg daily until patient can swallow (max. 7 days) Then A full 3-day course of recommended oral artemisinin combination therapy (ACT)

CHILDREN < 20 kg: 3 mg/kg 12 hourly Given at time 0 hour (i.e. on admission), at 12 hours and 24 hours Then 3.0 mg/kg daily until patient can swallow (max. 7 days) Then A full 3-day course of recommended oral ACT

Artesunate reconstitution for parenteral.Reconstitution: Use a syringe to draw and inject the solvent (sodium bicarbonate 50mg/ml solution) into the vial of artesunate powder. Shake the vial until the powder is completely dissolved and the solution is clear.
Artesunate reconstitution for parenteral.Intravenous injection: Add either glucose 50 mg/ml (i.e. 5% Dextrose solution) or sodium chloride 9 mg/ml (i.e. 0.9% Normal saline solution) to the re-constituted artesunate solution to create a 10 mg/ml solution of artesunate. Draw required volume and give slowly by IV at about 3-4 ml/min. If the required volume is more than 5 ml, divide it into two and inject at separate sites.
Artesunate reconstitution for parenteral.Intramuscular injection: Add either glucose 50 mg/ml (i.e. 5% Dextrose solution) or sodium chloride 9 mg/ml (i.e. 0.9% Normal saline solution) to the re-constituted artesunate solution to create a 20 mg/ml solution of artesunate. Draw required volume and give slowly by IM anterior thigh. If the required volume is more than 5 ml, divide it into two and inject at separate sites.

Severe or complicated malaria.Referral Criteria: Patients diagnosed as having severe malaria or who fail to respond to the recommended antimalarial medications must be referred. Appropriate treatment as indicated above must be initiated prior to transferring the patient. If referral is not possible immediately, continue the treatment regimen as shown above for severe malaria until referral is possible.

SEVERE PRE-ECLAMPSIA AND IMMINENT ECLAMP.Introduction: This is an obstetric emergency and must be treated urgently. Treatment is the same as that of eclampsia (see below). These cases are best managed in hospital under the supervision of an obstetrician. While blood pressure reduction is essential, lowering the blood pressure below 140/90mmHg may cause foetal distress and should be avoided. BP monitoring must be carried out every 15-30 minutes until the BP is reduced and the patient is stable. Thereafter monitoring can be done by 2-4 hourly. Daily weighing of the patient is essential.
Symptoms: Visual disturbances such as double vision (diplopia), blurred vision, flashes of light
Signs: Urine production of < 30 ml/hour or < 400 ml/24 hours
Investigations: Blood clotting profile (bedside clotting time, prothrombin time, INR, APTT)
Ultrasound scan for close foetal growth monitoring

Treatment Objectives: To reduce the blood pressure, but not lower than 140/90 mmHg
To prevent the mother from suffering from complications of the hypertension such as a stroke
To prevent fits/eclampsia
To stabilise the patient and deliver her if eclampsia is imminent
Non-pharmacological treatment: Early delivery of mother if eclampsia is imminent
If the patient is not symptomatic and the pregnancy is less than 34 weeks allow pregnancy to continue if the foetal condition would allow
If the pregnancy is 34 weeks or more consider delivery after stabilisation

Labetalol, IV, 20 mg stat. over at least 1 minute. Repeat at 10-minute intervals if the BP remains > 160/110 mm Hg...

Magnesium sulphate, IM, 10 ml of the 50% solution, (5 g) into each buttock (total of 10 g)

When the 'obstetrician' considers that the foetus is immature, the patient should be transferred to a hospital capable of looking after the immature baby.

Neonates, Pre-Pubertal, and Pubertal Chi.Introduction: Neonates, pre-pubertal, and pubertal children are also at risk of contracting STIs. The modes of transmission in these children are mostly through maternal infections, sexual abuse or exploitation, and voluntary sexual activity in older children. The STIs in this age group include neonatal conjunctivitis (ophthalmia neonatorum) and other STI-related syndromes similar to that in adults. Some of these STIs (e.g., gonorrhea, syphilis, and chlamydia), if acquired after the neonatal period, are indicative of sexual contact. For other STIs (e.g. HPV infections and vaginitis), the association with sexual contact is not clear.

Shock.Introduction: Shock is a clinical state of cellular dysfunction as a result of decreased circulating blood volume leading to a reduction in the delivery of oxygen and other nutrients to vital organs, which, if prolonged, leads to irreversible multiple organ failure.
Causes: Hypovolemia (e.g. hemorrhage, vomiting, diarrhea, acute intestinal obstruction)
Cardiogenic (e.g. myocardial infarction, massive pulmonary embolus)
Investigations: Septic screen if sepsis is suspected
CXR, ECG and Echocardiogram if cardiogenic shock suspected
Supportive tests like FBC, BUE, Creatinine and LFT is done to detect any derangement and correct them

Treatment Objectives: To reverse shock
To secure airway, breathing, and circulation
To prevent complications and multiple organ failure
To prevent death

Hypovolaemic shock: Insert the largest bore cannula (size 14 or 16) in the largest vein visible...
Raise drip stand or squeeze bag to increase infusion rate...
In haemorrhagic states cross-matched blood is preferred but in the meantime resuscitate with crystalloids e.g. normal saline...
Normal saline should be given quickly and slowed only when BP rises and urine flow is adequate...
Catheterise the bladder to monitor the urine output...
Oxygen, nasally or by facial masks, 6 L/minute...
Pharmacological treatment.Multiple Organ Dysfunction Syndrome: This is a life-threatening complication of shock. Different organs may be affected moderately or severely...
Pharmacological treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer all patients to the appropriate physician specialist.

Term Newborn (Neonate).Introduction: The term newborn (neonate) refers to a baby in the first month of life. At birth, all healthy newborns are active with a strong cry. Any baby born ill will show signs of poor activity or may be described as 'being flat' or floppy in severe cases. The newborn with one or more abnormal vital signs is unwell. These include color, activity, temperature, respiration, heart rate, blood sugar, urine output, nature of bowel movements, signs of distress (pain).
Causes: Congenital malformations (e.g. heart, central nervous system, bowel, etc.)
Maternal sedation or analgesia during labor
Symptoms: Weak cry or inability to cry
Difficulty in breathing or recurrent cessation of breathing (apnea)
Reduced spontaneous movements or being very floppy
Signs: Tenderness of any part of the body
Investigations: Chest X-ray in case of ACS
Blood and urine C/S when infection suspected

Treatment Objectives: To diagnose and treat underlying cause appropriately
To identify and manage the precipitating cause of crises
To maintain a good steady-state hemoglobin
To prevent permanent organ damage
Non-pharmacological treatment: Establish airway, ensure breathing, and adequate circulation (ABC)
Keep baby warm either wrapped up in dry clothes or in an incubator

Pharmacological treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer the patient urgently to a specialist for further investigations and treatment if no improvement after 48 hours.

Sickle Cell Disease.Introduction: This is an inherited disease characterized by the possession of two abnormal hemoglobins, at least one of which is hemoglobin S. There are various types, including HBSS, HBSC, and HBS thalassemia. The possession of one normal hemoglobin (hemoglobin A) together with one abnormal hemoglobin (e.g. AS or AC) constitutes a hemoglobinopathy trait and not sickle cell disease. Patients with sickle cell disease may present in the steady state, in crises, or with complications. The crisis is commonly vaso-occlusive bone pain crisis. Other types of crises include acute chest syndrome, hyper-hemolytic crisis, aplastic crisis, and sequestration crises.
Symptoms: Joint and bone pain, especially during cold wet seasons
Difficulty in breathing with or without chest pain
Abdominal pain, especially in the splenic area
Spontaneous sustained erection without sexual arousal in male patients
Signs: Splenomegaly (may be absent in older patients)
Old or recent scarification marks by traditional healers...
Growth delay or tall, lanky stature ('marfanoid' habitus)
Investigations: Plain abdominal X-ray, erect and supine if indicated
Cerebrospinal fluid biochemistry and culture and sensitivity

Treatment Objectives: To prevent the development of sickle cell crises
To relieve pain
To identify and manage the precipitating cause of crises
To prevent long term complications and organ damage
To manage sickle cell crises and complications once developed
Non-pharmacological treatment: Good hydration at all times by drinking adequate water/fluids
Avoidance of common precipitating causes of crises...
Genetic counseling with voluntary family size restriction

Mild to moderate pain: Dextrose in Sodium Chloride, IV Infusion...

Severe Pain: Blood transfusion (packed cells) when needed, but not routine...

Folic Acid, oral: Children: 1 year; 5 mg daily, < 1 year; 2.5 mg daily

Pharmacological treatment.Severe Disease: Amoxicillin + Clavulanic Acid, IV, 1.2 g and urgently transferred to a tertiary center...
Pharmacological treatment.Prevention of Pneumococcal Infections: Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine 13 (PCV 13) vaccination in infancy, booster at 6 years
Pharmacological treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer all sickle cell patients with bleeding into the eye, priapism, haematuria or renal disease and stroke to a specialist...

Sickle Cell Disease in Pregnancy.Introduction: Pregnancy in the Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) patient is associated with poor obstetric outcomes for both the mother and her baby. Common complications include miscarriages, vaso-occlusive crises, severe anemia, urinary tract infections, acute chest syndrome, preterm labor, and pulmonary embolism.
Sickle Cell Disease in Pregnancy.Multidisciplinary Team: Care by a multidisciplinary team consisting of Obstetricians, Physician specialists, Hematologists, Clinical Pharmacists, Anesthetists, Nurses, and Midwives ensures better health outcomes for these patients.

RDT or blood film for malaria parasites
Midstream urine for Culture and sensitivity at booking and whenever indicated

Treatment Objectives: Identify patients with condition early during pregnancy for closer monitoring
Correct anemia
Prevent known crises triggers
Detect and manage promptly all associated complications and crises
Deliver client safely as soon as baby is viable
Non-pharmacological treatment: Assist patient to plan pregnancy in optimum health
Educate on potential risks of SCD in Pregnancy

At Booking: Assess patient carefully for risk of frequent crises and previous obstetric complications
Examine for nutritional status, anemia, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly
Perform ultrasound to date pregnancy and exclude fetal abnormalities and growth retardation
Perform listed investigations to screen for and detect complications
Manage identified problems at booking appropriately and promptly
Follow-up Visits: Low-risk: schedule follow-up visits based on gestational age
Enquire about maternal well-being, crises symptoms, infection, and fetal growth
Examine for pallor, jaundice, fever, and proteinuria

Deliver in hospital; involve experienced midwives and obstetricians
Vaginal delivery until term; induction if necessary

Check for complications, counsel on avoiding crises triggers
Encourage early ambulation, review client postpartum, refer for continuing care
Counsel on family planning and offer contraception

Investigations: Sickling and Hb Electrophoresis (if not previously known)

Poisoning.Introduction: Poisoning represents the harmful effects of toxic amounts of any substance on the body. In many cases, only mild symptoms and signs will develop. However, suspected poisoning should always be considered a medical emergency since the situation may rapidly evolve to become critical. Many deaths due to poisoning can be prevented with early initiation of good supportive care and general treatment measures. Symptoms and signs of poisoning depend on the specific exposure, and may be local, systemic, or both. Effects may occur immediately, or several hours or days later. The severity depends on many factors, including the type of substance, the route of exposure (ingestion, inhalation, injection, dermal application, etc.), the dose and duration of exposure, and patient or environmental factors. Obtaining the original container or a sample of the substance is often most helpful, along with a thorough history and physical examination and laboratory analysis to look for characteristic features of poisoning with specific agents. Judicious use of antidotes for poisoning with specific substances may be added to general treatment measures based on these findings. A Poison Control Centre exists in Ghana to support health professionals in developing rational and timely strategies for diagnosis and treatment of poisoning.
SIGNS: Abnormal vital signs (pulse, temperature, respiratory rate)
Low urine output (oliguria, anuria) or retention
Poisoning.Note: Investigations should be individualized to the exposure. The Poisons Control Centre and/or clinical pharmacologist may advise in specific cases.

Non-Pharmacological: Reduce stress and encourage relaxation in masticatory apparatus
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer cases to the dentist for further management.

Testicular Torsion.introduction: Cessation of blood supply to the testis due to twisting of the spermatic cord, a medical emergency.
Symptoms: Sudden onset of acute severe pain in one testicle or recurrent pain
Pain may occur typically early in the morning
Lower abdominal pain on affected side
Signs: Swollen, tender, and abnormal position of testis and epididymis
Rigid abdomen and stiff neck and limbs

Objectives: Surgical intervention within 6 hours of onset
Treatment.Non-Pharmacological: Emergency surgery is the standard treatment
Pharmacological: Lignocaine 1%, into the spermatic cord on both sides
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer as soon as possible to a surgeon or urologist.

Tetanus.introduction: A disease caused by Clostridium tetani bacteria that produces neurotoxin.
Symptoms: Difficulty or inability to open mouth
Spasms triggered by noise, bright light, or touch
Signs: Rigid abdomen and stiff neck and limbs

Objectives: Eliminate Clostridium tetani and stop toxin production
Provide hydration, nutrition, and supportive care
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer patients to a specialist if spasms cannot be controlled.

Acutely Disturbed Patient.introduction: Patients presenting in an excited, agitated, or aggressive state with delusions and perceptual changes.
Symptoms: Hearing or seeing 'imaginary' people or objects
Expression of fear, undue suspicion, inappropriate guilt or bizarre beliefs
Signs: Elated, irritable, angry or depressed mood
Investigations: FBC, Rapid Diagnostic Test for malaria parasites

Non-Pharmacological: Talk to the patient in a firm but reassuring manner
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer all acutely disturbed patients to a specialist.

The Empty Scrotum.introduction: Refers to the absence of testis(es) in the scrotum/hemiscrotum.
Causes: Associated with anomalies like Prune Belly syndrome and hypospadias
Symptoms: Absence of one or both testes
In children, parents or the health worker may notice this at birth
The Empty Scrotum.Signs: Absent testis in both supine and upright positions
The Empty Scrotum.Investigations: Ultrasound scan of abdomen, pelvis and inguinal canal

Objectives: To avoid social and psychological complications
Treatment.Non-Pharmacological: Surgical intervention before two years of age. (All ectopic testes should be operated because they will not descend)
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer patients aged over one year with no evidence of testicular descent to a urologist or surgical specialist.

Unconsciousness.introduction: Unconsciousness is a common clinical problem and may be associated with diseases of several organs in the body.
Causes: Drug ingestion or overdose e.g. alcohol, salicylates, barbiturates, cocaine
Major organ failure e.g. hepatic failure, renal failure and myocardial infarction

Objectives: To support life until consciousness is regained
To prevent complications e.g. aspiration, hypoxia
To determine the underlying cause and manage it appropriately
Non-Pharmacological: Ensure the airway is patent and clear of secretions
Examine and stabilize the cervical spine if any history or sign of injury
Catheterize and monitor urine output if necessary
Place the patient in a position that would prevent aspiration in case of vomiting or pass an NG tube if no contraindications exist
Treatment.Pharmacological: Treat based on the identified underlying cause
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer to a specialist for further definitive management if not responding to standard measures of resuscitation.

Hypoglycemia.introduction: Hypoglycemia refers to a blood glucose level below 3.6 mmol/L.
Causes: Overdose of any anti-hyperglycemic medication i.e. insulin or oral agent
Antihyperglycemic medication use in renal impairment and the elderly
Omitted or inadequate amount of food
Symptoms: Shaking of the hands and body
Irritability and abnormal behaviour especially in children
Investigations: Random blood glucose (urgently done using a glucose meter)

Objectives: To rapidly restore blood glucose levels to normal
To maintain the level of blood glucose within the normal range until the patient can begin eating normally
To identify and address the cause
Non-Pharmacological: Mild hypoglycemia: 2-3 teaspoons of granulated sugar or 3 cubes of sugar or ½ a bottle of soft drink (sugar-containing, not 'diet' drinks) to individuals who are conscious.
Moderate hypoglycemia: Same as for mild hypoglycemia, but repeat after 10 minutes. If no improvement is observed, treat as for severe hypoglycemia
Pharmacological: Severe hypoglycemia 1st Line Treatment: Dextrose, IV
Prednisolone, oral (in cases of TB meningitis and TB pericarditis)
Treatment.Referral Criteria: If the patient does not respond to the above treatment recommendations, refer to a specialist.

Trigeminal Neuralgia.introduction: Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by unilateral facial pain that follows the distribution of the trigeminal nerve.
Symptoms: Sudden sharp-shooting pain in the face
Investigations: X-ray to rule out a fractured tooth
MRI to rule out intracranial pathology

Pharmacological: For the control of anxiety 1st Line Treatment: Diazepam, oral
For treatment of neuropathic pain 1st Line Treatment: Carbamazepine, oral
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer to the neurologist for further management.

Tuberculosis.introduction: Tuberculosis (TB) may affect any part of the body, but the commonest site is the lung (Pulmonary TB).
Causes: M. microti, M. kansasii and M. malmoensi (rarer causes)

Adults: Cough often for 2 weeks or more
Children: All adult symptoms and the following
Back pain and/or lower limb weakness
Vomiting and impaired consciousness (due to TB meningitis)

Signs: Signs of pneumonia or pleural effusion
Neck stiffness, altered level of consciousness in TB meningitis
Spinal tenderness, gibbus, paraplegia/paresis in Pott's disease
Investigations: Liver function test (for monitoring medication side effects)

Objectives: To prevent the development of drug resistance
To investigate close contacts. Where a child is affected, always check adult contacts with a productive cough
Treatment.Pharmacological: Refer to the TB Client Card (TB 01) for guidance on formulations and dosing by weight
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer to appropriate specialist as soon as diagnosis is made.

Bone and Joint Tuberculosis.introduction: Tuberculosis can affect all bones and joints.
Investigations: Chest X-ray to rule out pulmonary TB
Bone and soft tissue biopsy for culture and histology

Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer to appropriate specialist as soon as diagnosis is made.

Typhoid_Fever.Description: Typhoid fever (enteric fever) is a severe bacterial illness, occurring where sanitary conditions are poor, permitting contamination of food or water with faeces. The bacteria spread by the faeco-oral route invade the intestinal wall and spread through the bloodstream to all organs.
Complications: Severe intravascular haemolysis leading to acute kidney injury (especially in G6PD deficiency)

Prevention.Public_Education: Public education on good personal hygiene, hand washing, and appropriate disposal of solid waste
Prevention.Screening_Food_Handlers: Screening of food handlers by carrying out stool cultures to exclude carrier status and safe handling of food, fruits, and vegetables

Symptoms: Fever which increases gradually to a high fever and persists for weeks (fever does not respond to antimalarials)
Abdominal pain and diarrhea in the second week of illness
Signs: High fever with a relatively slow pulse rate (occasionally pulse is fast especially with myocarditis or intestinal perforation)
Investigations: RDT / blood film for malaria parasite (to exclude malaria)
Typhoid_Fever.Diagnosis_Notes: Diagnosis of typhoid fever is based on a strong clinical suspicion backed by various tests.

Objectives: Prevent transmission of infection to other people

NonPharmacological.Tepid_Sponging: Tepid sponging to reduce body temperature if required

1st_Line_Treatment.Ciprofloxacin_Oral: Ciprofloxacin, oral, Adults 500 mg 12 hourly for 10-14 days, Children 10 mg/kg 12 hourly for 10-14 days
1st_Line_Treatment.Ciprofloxacin_IV: Ciprofloxacin, IV, Adults 400 mg 8-12 hourly for 10-14 days, Children 10 mg/kg (max. 400 mg) 12 hourly for 10-14 days
1st_Line_Treatment.Note: Ciprofloxacin should be used with caution in children. Alternative treatment should be started in case of tendinitis.

2nd_Line_Treatment.Ceftriaxone_IV: Ceftriaxone, IV, Adults 2-4 g daily for 7-10 days, Children 100 mg/kg daily for 7-10 days
2nd_Line_Treatment.Azithromycin_Oral: Azithromycin, oral, Adults 500 mg daily for 7 days, Children 10-20 mg/kg for 7 days

Treatment.Referral_Criteria: Refer very ill patients and those with complications to the appropriate specialist. Healthy carriers should also be referred for specialist management.

Urinary Schistosomiasis.introduction: Urinary schistosomiasis is a water-borne disease caused by penetration of the skin or mucous membranes by the early stages of the causative organism (Schistosoma haematobium).

Initial: Itching and redness of skin at site of parasite penetration

Signs: Palpable kidney from hydronephrosis due to ureteric stricture
Palpable bladder from bladder cancer or retention of urine due to clots or bladder neck stenosis
Investigations: Urine for red blood cells, pus cells, and schistosoma ova
Imaging: Ultrasound scan; Intravenous Urogram(IVU) may show calcification of bladder, ureters, hydronephrosis and hydroureters

Treatment.Non-Pharmacological: Avoid repeated exposure to infested water bodies if possible
Treatment.Pharmacological: Praziquantel, oral, Adults and Children 40 mg/kg as a single dose
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer patient after adequate treatment if haematuria and/or symptoms of urinary infection persist or if complications are present.

Urinary Tract Calculi.introduction: Urinary tract calculi are crystal-like objects that form in various parts of the urinary tract. They consist mainly of mineral salts.
Causes: Foreign body including urinary catheter and suture material
Inborn errors of metabolism e.g. Cystinuria
Investigations: Serum uric acid, calcium, phosphate, magnesium

Objectives: To control pain during acute attack
To aid passage of the calculus or ensure complete removal
To prevent recurrence if the cause is known
Non-Pharmacological: Encourage oral fluid intake (2-3 L daily in an adult) and avoid dehydration
Manage acute urinary retention due to bladder or urethral stones by catheterisation or suprapubic cystostomy
Pharmacological: Pethidine, IM, 100 mg 4 hourly as required
Mebeverine, oral, 135 mg 8 hourly may be useful
Give antibiotics if urinary tract infection is present
Treatment.Referral Criteria: Refer to a urologist or surgical specialist for definitive treatment after initial management.

Retention of Urine.introduction: Retention of urine is the inability to empty a full bladder. It is the commonest urological emergency in Ghana and worldwide.

Causes.Adult males (above 50 years): BPH, urethral strictures, bladder neck stenosis
Causes.Adult males (below 50 years/young males): Urethral strictures, urethral injuries, bladder neck stenosis, neurogenic bladder/spinal injury, paraphimosis, urethral calculi, acute prostatitis
Causes.Male children: Posterior urethral valves, meatal stenosis, phimosis, urethral calculi, congenital strictures
Causes.Adult females: Retroverted gravid uterus, uterine fibroids/myomas, impacted ovarian cysts, neurogenic (postoperative and pelvic inflammatory disease), carcinoma of cervix with infiltration into the urethra

Symptoms: Retention of urine in BPH precipitated by postponement of micturition, alcohol abuse, and infection
Sudden inability to pass urine with painful bulge in lower abdomen for acute retention of urine
Gradual onset of inability to pass urine with painless bulge in lower abdomen for chronic retention of urine
Signs: Palpable tender bladder in acute retention of urine
Palpable non-tender bladder for chronic retention of urine
Fever in infections: UTI and prostatitis
Haematuria in BPH, prostate cancer, and urethral strictures
Retention of Urine.Referral Criteria: Patients with hydronephroses on ultrasound scan and renal failure should be referred to a specialist.

Urticaria.introduction: Urticaria or wheal is a transient, itchy swelling of the skin secondary to the release of histamine.
Investigations: Full blood count (may show eosinophilia related to allergy or parasitic infestation or low white blood count from systemic lupus erythematosus)
Thyroid antibodies and function (in chronic urticaria if autoimmune origin is considered likely)
Skin biopsy (if wheals are prolonged, to identify vasculitis)

Objectives: To prevent complications such as anaphylaxis, shock or asphyxiation
To identify possible underlying cause and address it
Treatment.Non-Pharmacological: Avoid contact with or further use of the suspected allergen or causative agent

Urticaria.Referral Criteria: Refer all patients in whom vomiting persists or who show signs of progression in disease, patients with unexplained or persistent vomiting, and patients with suspected surgical cause of vomiting for specialist or surgical assessment and management.

Urinary Tract Infection.introduction: Urinary tract infection (UTI) is the presence of micro-organisms in the urine or tissues of the normally sterile genitourinary tract.
Symptoms: Feeding problems, diarrhoea, and failure to thrive (in children)
Investigations: Mid-stream specimen of urine for microscopy, culture and sensitivity
Abdominal ultrasound scan in children if indicated

Objectives: To relieve symptoms such as fever and pain
To identify patients with abnormalities of the genito-urinary tract
Non-Pharmacological: Surgical intervention in suspected intestinal obstruction, peritonitis

Post-operative treatment: Doxorubicin, IV (depending on stage and risk category)
Cyclophosphamide IV in combination (For high risk tumours)

Urinary Tract Infection.Referral Criteria: All patients should be referred to specialist centres for appropriate treatment.

Worm Infestation.introduction: Infestation with worms is very common. Poor hygiene or contact of bare skin with soil in which the worm or its eggs live predisposes individuals to infestation.
Symptoms: Dry cough (when the larvae pass through the lungs)
Wheeze (when the larvae pass through the lungs)
Passage of worm(s) in the stool

Objectives: To treat the complications of infestation e.g. anaemia, malnutrition
Non-Pharmacological: Proper hand washing with soap and running water

administration.Or: Tiabendazole (Thiabendazole), oral, Adults - 1.5 g 12 hourly for 3 days, Children - 25 mg/kg 12 hourly for 3 days

administration.Adults and children: 5-10 mg/kg as a single dose. (25 mg/kg as a single dose for Hymenolepis nana; repeated in 10 days)

Worm Infestation.Referral Criteria: Refer patients with intestinal obstruction from a heavy load of suspected worm infestation to a surgical specialist.

Wilms Tumour.introduction: Wilms tumour (nephroblastoma) is a malignant embryonal tumour of renal tissue.
Symptoms: Visible and or palpable abdominal mass
Signs: Abdominal mass (palpate with care to prevent rupture or dissemination)

Objectives: To provide adequate supportive and palliative care

Post-operative treatment: Doxorubicin, IV (depending on stage and risk category)
Cyclophosphamide IV in combination (For high risk tumours)

Wilms Tumour.Referral Criteria: Refer all patients to specialist centres for appropriate treatment.

Wound.introduction: A wound is a break in the continuity of tissues in the body. It may involve overlying epithelium like skin. Wounds are usually caused by injury. Tissues affected include subcutaneous tissue, muscles and even bones. It may be small or large and may be deep or superficial. It may bleed, may be contaminated with dirt and other foreign matter and become infected.
Causes: Mechanical agents e.g. cut from cutlass or knife, gunshot, accidents, contusion from blunt injury.
Chemical agents e.g. strong acids or alkalis, other corrosive chemicals
Signs: Look for other injuries e.g., head, chest, abdomen, bone, nerves
Determine the physical characteristics of the wound e.g. site, size, shape and depth
Investigations: Haemoglobin level if patient has bled
Group and cross-match blood if indicated
X-ray of injured part may be required to rule out osteomyelitis and bone fractures
Wound swab for culture and sensitivity if wound is infected

Non-Pharmacological: Apply sterile pressure dressing to bleeding site and raise the injured part to control bleeding.
If a bleeding vessel can be identified, it should be ligated. (the use of tourniquet to stop bleeding is discouraged)
Bleeding from a tooth socket - put a small piece of sterile gauze in the socket and ask the patient to bite on it.

Immediate closure of wounds is good, but this is not advisable if the wound is dirty or likely to become infected e.g. gunshot wounds, animal and human bites and wounds over 6 hours old. They should not be sewn up.
Wash hands well and wear sterile gloves. Clean the wound with antiseptic solution. Scrub dirty wounds with antiseptic solution and irrigate with dilute hydrogen peroxide and saline.
If there are bits of gravel, glass or dirt in the wound, remove them gently. Lift up all flaps of skin, clean under them, excise all dead tissue and cover the wound with sterile gauze.
Do not use Eusol, which is both irritant and exposes patient to unnecessary borate levels

Dress infected wound as often as needed with normal saline or povidone iodine lotion. Take wound swab for culture and sensitivity test if possible and start Amoxicillin while waiting for results of wound culture.

1st Line Treatment.Tetanus prophylaxis: for all potentially contaminated wounds, followed by booster doses of tetanus toxoid as appropriate
Paracetamol: Children: 6-12 years: 250-500 mg 6-8 hourly, 1-5 years: 120-250 mg 6-8 hourly, 3 months-1 year: 60-120 mg 6-8 hourly
Amoxicillin: Children: 6-12 years: 250 mg 8 hourly, 1-5 years: 125 mg 8 hourly, 1 year: 62.5 mg 8 hourly

Wound.Referral Criteria: Refer complicated wounds (e.g. wounds associated with fractures, division of tendons, blood vessels and nerves) to specialist care.

Vitamin A Deficiency.introduction: This condition is common in children. It is associated with inadequate intake of foods that contain Vitamin A. It is a common cause of blindness in children. It is important to prevent this condition by examining the eyes of all sick and malnourished children. The diet of children should include foods that contain Vitamin A (dark green leafy vegetables e.g. nkontomire, yellow fruits and vegetables, palm oil, milk, eggs). Parents and other caregivers should be discouraged from putting any traditional preparations such as herbs, sea water, saliva, urine, etc. or drugs into the eye unless prescribed by a physician.
Symptoms: Poor night vision (in the early stages)
Signs: Keratomalacia (cloudy cornea, soft and easy ulceration)

Objectives: To recognize and correct vitamin A deficiency
Treatment.Non-Pharmacological: High vitamin A containing foods should be encouraged

Vitamin A Deficiency.Referral Criteria: Refer all established cases of xerophthalmia to an eye specialist if the condition is severe with an uneven or bulging cornea.

Yaws.introduction: Yaws is a chronic infection by a bacterium that affects mainly the skin, bone and cartilage. Most people affected are children under 15 years of age but adults are not exempt. It is transmitted mainly through skin contact with an infected person. A single skin lesion develops at the point of entry of the bacterium after 24 weeks. Without treatment, multiple lesions appear all over the body. The disease is rarely fatal, however it can lead to chronic disfigurement and disability in about 10% of affected individuals if left untreated. Treatment with antibiotics is curative and relapse is rare. Overcrowding, poor personal hygiene and poor sanitation facilitate the spread of the disease.

Objectives: To eradicate the organism and ensure cure
To prevent spread of the infection

Azithromycin.Adults: 30 mg/kg body weight (max. 2 g) as a single dose

Yaws.Referral Criteria: Refer intractable cases to the dermatologist.

Yellow Fever.introduction: Yellow fever is caused by a virus transmitted to man by a species of mosquitoes (Aedes aegypti) from infected monkeys. The disease is not spread from person to person. Classical yellow fever is usually fatal. After the onset of symptoms, there is a brief remission of 2-24 hours, following which the symptoms may recur with the development of epigastric pain, jaundice, renal insufficiency, cardiovascular instability and bleeding from various sites (e.g. gums and needle-puncture sites). Yellow fever vaccination is protective against the disease and needs to be repeated every ten years. Yellow fever vaccination is a requirement for travel from Ghana to several countries.
Signs: Bleeding from various sites (petechiae, ecchymosis, etc.)
Investigations: Urinalysis - proteinuria and raised urobilinogen levels
Blood sample for yellow fever virus serology (at the Regional Public Health Reference Laboratory)

Objectives: To provide supportive care for hepatic, renal and circulatory failure
Non-Pharmacological: If yellow fever is suspected in a patient, admit immediately to an isolation ward
Full supportive treatment for hepatic failure and acute renal failure

Yellow Fever.Referral Criteria: Refer to a hospital, preferably one with an isolation unit.
